former_owner_as_recorded: Abbazia di Morimondo|Acquafredda (Monastery : Milan, Italy)|Giovio, Paolo, 1483-1552|Giovio, Francesco, active 19th century|Martini, Giuseppe, 1870-1944|Moffitt, James K. 1865-1955
physical_description: Extent: 144 leaves : parchment ; 240 x 160 (175 x 113) mm bound to 244 x 161 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 1021:2) & positive (BANC MS UCB 16 FILM)
note: Transferred from abbey of origin at Morimondo to the daughter abbey of Acquafredda in Como at the beginning of 13th cent. (on last flyleaf is written in a 13th cent hand: "Liber Sancte Marie de Aqua Frigida"). Formerly in possession of Joseph Martini (catalogue 26, no. 12), who falsely attributed it to have been in the library of Paolo Giovio of Como (1483-1552); likely from the library of Francesco Giovio instead -- see Ferrari, M. "Dopo Bernardo: biblioteche e 'scriptoria' cisterciensi dell'Italia settentrionale nel XII secolo. In San Bernardo e l'Italia, [253]-306. Bequest of James K. Moffitt to The Bancroft Library|Ms. codex.|Title from modern inscription on front pastedown.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 144 + ii (2nd flyleaf now pastedown); 18 (+ half sheet added for table and preface of Genesis) 2-68 78 (+ one-third sheet added for table of Exodus) 8-108 118 (+ one-fourth sheet added for table of Numbers) 12-138 146 (+2) 15-178 186 (+2); catchwords at the end of each quire; quires 3 and 4 signed "iiii"; quire 6 signed "vi."|Layout: 22-23 long lines; ruled in lead.|Script: Written in a Caroline-gothic script by one hand; additions written by several other hands.|Decoration: 7 contemporary pen-and-ink drawings in margins, some touched in red, of a snake, fish, geometrical forms, grotesque and chimerical animals; 3- 11-line initials in red, decorated in void, some with pen-flourishing in black; 1-line initials within text in red and green; corrections in the text, marginalia and commentary often enclosed in a decorated frame.|Binding: 17th cent. goatskin over contemporary thick wooden boards cut square; top cover detached.|Origin: Probably written in the Cistercian abbey of Morimondo (founded Nov. 10, 1134, Diocese of Milan), to judge by the entry "Item Ysidorus super vetum testamentum" in an inventory of books of this monastery (inventory is part of a lectionary in the collection of Philip Hofer, De Ricci, p. 1693, no. 5), and also by the characteristic script.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 16.|Former shelfmark: MAR 23.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS1145.I8.

note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii (paper) + 24 + ii (paper); 1-38; foliated 110-132 in the 15th cent.|Layout: 19 lines of Biblical text in central column; ruled in dry point. Gloss primarily in 2 columns on either side of main text, and ruled in 46 lines. Some interlinear gloss and some gloss in top and bottom margins.|Script: Gothic. Biblical text in black ink in one hand; gloss in brown ink in several hands.|Decoration: 4 3-line foliate initials in red.|Binding: Middle Hill boards. Back end paper has watermark (ogre with staff; underneath, initials "HMN"); not in Bricquet. Spine crumbling. Paper reinforcement, visible through back pastedown, has German Gothic printing.|Origin: Produced in France in the 1st quarter of the 12th cent. as part of larger glossed New Testament.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 18.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS2632.L15.

physical_description: Extent: 61 leaves : parchment ; 143 x 105 (100-102 x 61) mm bound to 151 x 111 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 1034:7) & positive (BANC MS UCB 20 FILM)
note: Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 61; 1-28 34 4-78 88 (+1 pasted in); quires 4-8 are signed a-e at center bottom of first folio of gathering.|Layout: 25 lines per page; line-ruled in lead with double lines on left.|Script: Gothic, in several hands and in both brown and black ink, 1-4 lines of majuscule accompanying large initials.|Decoration: Zoomorphic initial (fol. 21r) with beasts and foliage, blue and yellow in-filling and outlined in red. Other initials are 20 lines in dark blue on green ground (fol. 2v); 13-line in blue with orange and green foliate and silver in-filling, on stipled yellow ground; and 8-line initial in orange on silver and blue ground with green and blue (fol. 1r). Secondary initials are 3-line initials in red and blue. 1-line initials alternate in red and blue. Line fillers in red.|Binding: 18th cent. full leather binding over boards, with gilt decoration on spine and edges of boards. Edges speckled in red and blue. On spine: "Ms Theol. 4° 81" pasted on. On front pastedown: "6/6 " crossed out; then "6/5 [615?]" written.|Origin: Produced in Germany in the 12th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 20.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS2833 L15.|1. fol. 1r-2v: "[letter of Cromatius and Heliodorus to Jerome] Partum Marie Virginis regine virginum: simul et navitatem atque infanciam domini Jesu Christi in ypoc[r]ifis libris invenimus ... quod idoneum est sanctis ac beatissimis Cromatio et Eliodoro episcopis Ieronimus exiguus Christi servus in domino salutem."|2. fol. 2v: "[Jerome's response] Qui terram auri consciam fodit ... qui ad salvatoris nostris sanctam infanciam per nostram potuerint obedienciam prevenire."|5. fol. 47r-56r: "[Pilate's letter to Claudius] Et ipso hec Pilatus scripnt [sic] epistolam ad urbem Romam Claudio dicens Poncius Pilatus Claudio suo salutem ... Quia ipsum credimus dei filium qui cum patre et spiritu sancto vivit et regnat per omnia secula seculorum. Amen. Finit exilium Pilati."|6. fol. 56r-61v: "[oratio dominica] Pater noster qui es in celis et cetera. In hac oratione dominica vii pectitiones esse dinoscuntur ... A quo pater nos defendat Iesus Christus dominus noster qui vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen. Explicit liber omnino."

physical_description: Extent: 8 leaves : parchment ; 166 x 251 (50 x 140) mm bound to 172 x 252 mm
note: From the library of John Henry Nash.|Ms. codex.|Title adapted from opening sentence (fol. 1r).|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 8 + i; 18 (fol. 2 attached to second bifolium and folio excised between fol. 4 and 5.|Layout: Written in 6-10 long lines; vertical bounding lines ruled in lead.|Script: Fol. 1r-8r written in Gothic secretary, italic and humanistic scripts by one hand, namely that of Stephan Brechtl; fol. 8v possibly written by a second hand, signed "Ulricus Le[m?]p Egranus, Arithmeticus."|Decoration: Calligraphic elaborations heightened with gold ink on initials and on ascenders and descenders on top and bottom lines, sometimes extending to edge of folio.|Binding: Bound in modern vellum.|Origin: The author, Stephen Brechtl, writes on fol. 1r that he is a teacher of arithmetic in Nurnberg, and dates his work 1521.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 21.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BV247 K8.|Fol. 1r-8v: "[text] Kurze Furweisung, Kunstlichs unnd zerlichs schreibens ... Non nobis Domine non nobis sed nomini tuo do gloriam."

title_as_recorded: Hymnarium, sive, Hymni per circulum anni
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts|Catholic Church|Hymns, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Hymns, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Liturgics|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 26 leaves : parchment ; 112-116 x 78-80 (90-92 x 51-53) mm bound to 125 x 86 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 764:8) & positive (BANC MS UCB 22 FILM)
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii (paper) + 26 + ii (paper); 18 210( -2) 38 42.|Layout: 29 lines per page; line-ruled in lead with double ruling on edges of text. Prickings visible.|Script: Fol. 1r-26r in a small English Caroline minuscule, with some additions in a later gothic hand (cf. fol. 19r-v). Prayer on fol. 26r-v in a later (13th cent.) gothic hand.|Decoration: 3-line initials in red, some with flourishes.|Music: Neumes over first line of text on fol. 1r.|Binding: Full modern leather, with blind tooling on edges of front and back covers. Title stamped in gold on spine: "Hymnarium. Cod. Saec. XII."|Origin: Produced in England in the 12th cent., probably for a monastic house (cf. "pro fratribus et sororibus nostris absentibus" on fol. 26v, and "chorus sacrarum virginum monachorumque omnium" on fol. 22r). Although this hymnal shares 57 hymns with the Use of Sarum, the text of these hymns often differs from that of the Sarum version, so it is unlikely that the hymnal represents the Use of Sarum (which, moreover, was not adopted in other dioceses until the early 13th cent.).|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 22.|Former shelfmark: MAR 22.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BV 468 H9.|1. fol. 1r-25v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt ymni per circulum anni. [text] Deus creator omnium polique rector vestiens diem decoro lumine noctem soporis gratia ... Gloria patri geniteque proli et tibi conpar utriusque semper spiritus alme deus uno omni tempore seculi. Amen."|2. fol. 25v-26r: "[rubr.] Preces in ieiunio [text] Oremus per omni gradu ecclesie. Sacerdotes tui indu[entur] ... Effunde frameam et conclude adv[er]sus eos qui per[sequuntur]. Dic anime mee."|3. fol. 26r-v: "[in a later hand] Omnes sancti tui quesumus domine nos oratio sancta ... Deus qui nos sanctorum tuorum Processi et Martiniani confessionibus gloriosis circumdas et protegis. Da nobis eorum imi[illegible due to heavy use] proficere et intercessione gaudere ..."

physical_description: Extent: 136 leaves : paper ; 147 x 105 (100-113 x 70-88) mm bound to 152 x 103 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 1048:6) & positive (BANC MS UCB 23 FILM)
note: Originally owned by Cardinal Domenico Passionei; the codex passed into the library of Joseph Martini, then into the library of Sidney G. Hamilton. Front pastedown: bookplate of Sidney Hamilton. Endsheet, verso: "Antonio ." Fol. 1r: ownership stamp of Cardinal Passionei ("Bibliothecae Passionae"), on either side, in pen, "Phillippi Monti" (in modern hand). Written in ink on top edge: "Diva c o[-?]."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, fol. i (parchment) + 136; foliated in pen 16-155, in modern pencil 1-136; 112 212 ( -1) 3-710 88 912 1010 (+4) 118 128 (+1) 1312; catchwords in some quires.|Layout: Varies due to large number of hands, but, in general, line-ruled in pale ink or lead, 30-36 lines; other sections frame-ruled; majority of codex is in 1 column, some sections in 2 columns.|Script: Gothic; at least 5 hands, writing with varying degress of formality.|Decoration: 3-line initial in blue (fol. 13r); some 1-2-line initials, occasionally with pen flourishes, sometimes in red; some initials missing (cf. fol. 3v).|Binding: Old red velvet over pasteboards; remains of fore-edge cloth ties.|Origin: Produced in Italy in the 15th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 23.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX885.B6.

note: Bequest of James K. Moffitt to The Bancroft Library.|Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubric (fol. 1r).|Collation: Parchment, i + 79 + i (pastedown) ; 1-810 ; catchwords at end of each quire.|Layout: 24 long lines; ruled in ink.|Script: Written in humanistic cursive in one hand.|Decoration: 2 4-line painted initials on square gold grounds; 2-line initials in alternating red and blue with pen flourishing of other color.|Binding: 15th cent. physical_description: Extent: 36 leaves : paper ; 283 x 204 (198 x 150) mm bound to 287 x 210 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 1050:1) & positive (BANC MS UCB 25 FILM)
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Edited by Giovanni Andrea Bussi.|Collation: Paper (very similar, if not identical, to Piccard, Buchstabe P, 7:979, Mecheln 1500), fol. v + 36 + iii; 1-312; quires 1 and 2 signed in red roman numerals on the first recto in the lower right corner; evidence of quire and leaf signatures as letters of the alphabet and arabic numerals; catchwords in a noting hand in the innermost corner of the last verso.|Layout: 2 columns of 39-45 lines ruled in lead with single horizontal bounding lines that cross the gutter but do not extend into the outer margins, and single vertical bounding lines full-length; prickings along outer edge of final leaves.|Script: Written in a bâtarde script with no loops.|Decoration: 4- and 6-line opening initials blue or red with void design; 3-, 2- and 1-line initials in red; initials within the text slashed in red.|Binding: Ca. 1825 in Dutch half-Russia (calf) over pasteboard; swirled marbled endpapers.|Origin: Manuscript was copied, directly or indirectly, from a printed book, in that G.A. Bussi's dedicatory letter first appeared in the editio princeps of Leo's sermons, printed in 1470 in Rome by Sweynheym and Pannartz.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, fMS UCB 25.|Former shelfmark: MAR 4.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX890 L4.|1. fol. 1r-v: "[rubr.] Iohannis andree episcopi aleriensis ad summum pontificem paulum secundum venetum epistola ad laudem ipsius sancti leonis pape. [text] Si tua michi o pater beatissime paule secunde venete romanorum pontifex maxime sanctitas antehac veniam tribuit ... Is igitur sit noster in terris instructor, in celis apud omnipotentem deum intercessor qui est in secula benedictus. Amen."|2. fol. 1v-2r: Contents list, giving for each sermon its occasion or liturgical feast, its ordinal number, and its incipit: "[rubr.] Sequuntur rubrice tocius operis per ordinem. [text] Beati leonis pape de assumpcione sua ad pontificatum gratiarum actionis Sermo primus, Laudem deo [sic] ... Tractatus beati leonis pape contra heresim Euticetis habitus Rome in basilica sancte Anastasie, Sicut peritus."

physical_description: Extent: 424 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 150 x 115 (116 x 83) mm. bound to 150 x 116 mm.
note: Coat of arms (now cropped) with 3 balls and in chief a lion passant, all within a laurel wreath supported by standing putti, added in simple style in the lower margin of fol. 13; modern notes in French on added slips of paper with monogram "B (V? and E)"; first slip of paper stamped on verso "PP. on. A. Hart," and signed "Zoisany" . Later belonged to John C. Cebrian of San Francisco.|Ms. codex.|Title from spine and from pseudo-gothic script on fol. ii.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii (modern parchment, the first of these glued to the verso of the endleaf) + 424 + ii (modern parchment, the second of these glued to the recto of the endleaf); 112 2-2010 218 22-2610 274 (through fol. 264) 28-3910 404 (through fol. 388) 41-4310 446 ( -6; + flyleaf); quires numbered unreliably in modern pencil on first leaf recto in lower right corner; catchwords enclosed in cartouche decorated with pale red and yellow washes and red dots. Contemporary foliation in red Roman numerals in upper center margin through fol. 44.|Layout: 2 columns of 33 lines ruled in lead for horizontal lines and in dry point for vertical bounding lines.|Script: Written in round gothic book hand in 2 sizes according to liturgical function, either by several scribes or by one scribe with varying control. Scribe 1, fol. 211-264v; possibly several scribes for remaining folios.|Decoration: 1 12-line historiated initial on square gold round (leaf 211v); 13 6-line painted initials on square gold rounds with broad, leafy extensions (leaves 13, 35v, 56, 154v, 160v, 211, 222, 227v, 231v, 236, 241v, 246v, 389); 1 6-line pen-flourished initial; 2-line initials in alternating red and blue with harping and beading in other color. Rubrics red throughout.|Binding: modern green morocco with gold-stamped dentelle on turn-ins.|Origin: Written in Italy, probably Florence, by the middle of the fourteenth cent. The book was written for Franciscan use.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 26.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2000 A3R6 1350.|1. fol. 1r-6v: Graded calendar in black ink for the saints' names, with grading, Easter finding notes, and zodiacal position of the sun in red: Zenobius (25 May), Anthony of Padua (13 June), John the Baptist (24 June, and octave 1 July), Donatus of Arezzo (7 August), Lawrence (10 August, and octave 17 August), Clare of Assisi (12 August), Louis of Toulouse (19 August), Louis king of France (25 August), Decollation of John the Baptist (29 August), Francis (4 October), Reparata (8 October), Cerbonius (10 October), Minias (25 October), Elisabeth of Hungary (19 November), Zeno (8 December). Added to the calendar (not in the main body of the text) are: John Chrysostom (27 January), Thomas Aquinas (7 March), Patrick (here on 16 March), Joseph (19 March), Longinus (20 March), Vincent Ferrer (5 April), Crescentius (19 April), Bernardinus of Siena (20 May), Nicolas of Tolentino (10 September), Domninus (9 October), Donatus (22 October), Eugenius (17 November), Ansanus (1 December), Florentius (30 December).|5. fol. 211r-264v: Psalter with antiphons, versicles and responses, ending on fol. 263v-264v with "[text] Te lucis ante terminum (RH 20138), Nunc dimittis, Pater noster, Credo in deum patrem, Gloria in excelsis, Credo in unum deum."|6. fol. 265r-388v: Sanctorale of the breviary from Saturninus (29 November) through Catherine of Alexandria (25 November) including offices for the feasts of Zenobius, Anthony of Padua, John the Baptist (vigil, feast and octave, each with 9 lessons), Donatus of Arezzo, Lawrence (vigil, feast and octave), Clare of Assisi, Louis of Toulouse, Louis king of France, Decollation of John the Baptist, Francis, Reparata, Minias, Elisabeth of Hungary, Felicitas.|7. fol. 389r-408r: Common of saints.|8. fol. 408r-412r: Office of the Virgin, use of Rome, with seasonal changes.|9. fol. 412r-415r: Office of the dead, use of Rome.

physical_description: Extent: 102 leaves : parchment ; 171 x 135 (120-110 x 92) mm. bound to 172 x 140 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from existing description.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 102 (of original 104); 112 ( -1) 214 ( -3 after f. 13) 312 410 5-612 714 812 910 ( -1 after fol. 96; -8, 9, 10 after fol. 102); catchwords horizontally in lower right margin; contemporary foliation in early form of arabic numerals in upper margin.|Layout: 24-31 long lines; frame ruled in lead on 3 sides (omitting bottom).|Script: Written by 2 scribes in cursive miniscule: scribe 1, fol. 1r-84v; scribe 2, fol. 85r-102v.|Decoration: 2-line plain initials; initials within text slashed in red; paragraph marks and circles around holes in parchment in red.|Music: Notation on pastedowns 12th cent. neumes in campo aperto of the St. Gall type, without lines.|Binding: 15th cent. Dark brown calf over wooden boards cut flush with the book block, with simple blind ruling. Pastedowns from a noted Antiphonale. Evidence of 5 bosses on each cover, of fore edge straps closing from bottom to top, and of chain on lower center back cover. Binding severely damaged by worms.|Origin: Written during the 2nd half of the 15th cent. in Mainz for use in the cathedral church (Dom) of St. Martin, as evidenced by frequent textual references to Mainz, to St. Martin (as "maior ecclesia"), and to the Benedictine abbeys of St. Alban and St. James. Reference on leaf 90r-v to Gerhard, Archbishop of Mainz, 1289-1305, has caused some to date the manuscript to ca. 1305.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 27.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2017 M2.|1. fol. 1r-77r: Temporale beginning defectively in Monday of the first week of Advent through the 25th Sunday after Trinity (all texts by cue only).|3. fol. 102r-v: Common of saints (Apostles, Evangelists and Many Martyrs), breaking defectively (all texts by cue only).

title_as_recorded: Psalterium et preces ad usum Gandarum
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts|Église catholique--Liturgie--Textes|Catholic Church|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Manuscrits latins médiévaux et modernes--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscrits médiévaux--Californie--Berkeley|Liturgics|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 252 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 113 x 76 (67 x 46) mm. bound to 116 x 80 mm.
note: Presumably belonged to "E.R." during the late 15th cent. (fol. 252v); armorial bookplate of Francis Jack Needham, 2nd Earl of Kilmorey (1787-1880), on front pastedown. Later came into the library of Phoebe Apperson Hearst.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii (modern parchment) + 252 + ii (modern parchment); 1-910 1014 ( -2 after fol. 91; no loss of text) 11-1210 1310 (with 3rd and 4th bifolia reversed in binding) 14-2210 23-248 2514 ( -14); quire signatures as letters of the alphabet [f]-z, ad hoc symbol, aa-ff, suggest that 5 quires are missing at beginning of text.|Layout: 15 long lines ruled in brown ink with top 2 and bottom 2 lines full across; single vertical bounding lines full length.|Script: Written in gothic book hand with versals placed partially outside the written space. Written by 3 scribes: scribe 1, fol. 1r-248r; scribe 2, rubrics, antiphons; scribe 3, fol. 248v-252v.|Decoration: 7 8-line historiated initials on burnished gold grounds with silver frames; marginal grotesques; 3-line initials in gold with bold bar extension the length of text; 1-line initials in gold with pen flourishings of alternating pink and blue. Decor similar to the Psalter of Guy de Dampierre.|Binding: 19th cent. brown morocco, stamped on front and back covers with interlaced pattern; Aldine leaves stamped in compartments on spine, except in the 2nd compartment which bears label from previous binding, reading "Psalterium et preces MS Sec. XIV"; gilt edges.|Origin: Written towards the beginning of the 14th cent. in Ghent, judging by the use of the office of the dead and the saints in the litany, as well as by the book's style and overall layout.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 28.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2033 A2 1300.|1. fol. 1r-211r: Psalter (beginning defectively at Ps. 21).|2. fol. 211r-234r: Ferial canticles, Benedicite, Te deum, NT canticles, Quicumque vult.|4. fol. 238v-248r: Office of the dead.

note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 202 + ii; [bound too tightly to allow analysis of collation].|Layout: 15 lines per page; frame-ruled in pale red ink, with lines often running length of page. Fol. 92r-93v have 20 lines per page, with same ruling.|Script: Batarde, in 2 hands (scribe 2 added fol. 92r-93v).|Decoration: Miniature on fol. 101 (Pentecost). Border running length of text on most pages, with flowers and foliage in red, blue, and green with gold leaves. 4-line initials in blue with foliate decoration in blue and red on gold ground. 2-line initials in red with foliate decoration (blue, orange) on gold. 1-line initials in gold on blue and/or red. Line fillers in blue and red with gold and white decoration. Later decoration includes coat of arms of Graville (dimidiated with another coat of arms) on fol. 12v and 42v and initial on fol. 43r (added to disguise loss of text due to removal of illuminated illustration).|Binding: Full leather morocco binding with blind tooling on spine, outer boards and infolds, 5 raised bands; title stamped on spine: Livre d'Heures; gilt edges; bound by Chambolle-Duru.|Origin: Produced in France in the 15th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 31.|Former shelfmark: MAR 7.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2080 1460.|1. fol. 1r-12v: Calendar.|2. fol. 13r-18r, Gospel readings: "[beginning defective] erat ille lux sed ut testimonium perhiberet de lumine ... Illi autem profecti predicaverunt ubique domino quo operante et sermonem confirmante sequantibus signis. Deo gratias."|3. fol. 18r-27v: "[rubr.] Oracio beate Marie virginis [text] Obsecro te domina sancta Maria mater Dei ... [rubr.] Alia oracio beate Marie [text] O intemerata et in eternum benedicta ... cum sanctis et electis suis vitam et leticiam sempiternam per Christum dominum nostrum. Amen."|4. fol. 28r-40r: "[rubr.] Passio domini nostri Iesu Christi secundum Johannem. Gloria tibi Domine. [text] In illo tempore egressus Iesus trans torrentem Cedron ubi erat ortus ... Ibi ergo propter paracevenem Iudeorum quia iuxta erat monumentum ubi posuerunt Iesum."|7. fol. 55r-92r: "[beginning defective] ... fluctus suos a vocibus aquarum multarum. Mirabiles elaciones maris mirabilis in altis dominus ... per passionem eius et crucem ad resurrectionis gloriam perducamur per Christum dominum nostrum. Amen."|8. fol. 92r-93v: "[in a second hand] Deus propicius esto michi peccatori et custos mei omnibus diebus ... Qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto vivit et regnat Deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen."|9. fol. 94r-100v: "[beginning defective] ... ctam crucem tuam redemisti mundum oremus Domine [rubr.] Oracio [text] Iesu Christe fili Dei vivi pone passionem mortem et crucem tuam ... ut qui pro me passus est in mortis ardone [sic] sis michi solacium in mortis agone. Amen."|11. fol. 107r-127v: "Laboravi in gemitu meo lavabo per singulas noctes ... [rubr.] Letania [text] Kyri eleyson Christ [sic] eleyson Kyri eleyson Christe audi nos ... Ave salus mundi verbum patris hostia vera viva sacra caro deitas integra verus homo qui me formasti tu miserere mei. Amen."|12. fol. 128r-180v: "[beginning defective] ... dominus humiliatus sum et liberavit me ... Qui vivis et regnas Deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen."|13. fol. 181r-185v: "[rubr.] Devote et moult piteuse observacion de la vierge Maria. [text] Stabat mater dolorosa iuxta crucem lacrimosa ... Et Iesum benedictum fructum ventris tui nobis post hoc exilium ostende. O clemens O pia O dulcis Maria. Amen."|14. fol. 186r-194v: "Doulce dame de misericorde. Mere de pitie fontaine de tous biens ... Deffens mon corps de mescheance et mottroye par ton plaisir. Q[ue?] ie puisse confesse mourir. Amen."|16. fol. 198-202v: "O sancte Sebastiane semper vespere et mane horis cunctis et momentis dum adhuc ... presta quesumus ut eius meritis et pretibus et intercessione ad montem qui Christus est valeamus pervenire per Christum dominum nostrum. Amen."

subject_as_recorded: Servites--Biography|Servites|Patrizi, Francesco, 1275-1328|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Manuscrits latins médiévaux et modernes--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscrits médiévaux--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 45 leaves : parchment, col. ill., port. ; 172 x 115 (114 x 55) mm. bound to 180 x 116-120 mm.
note: The work is dedicated to Pope Pius II (Enea Silvio Piccolomini). It later passed into the library of Thomas Thorpe and then into that of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 7380). On inner front binding: "7380 Ph" in modern pencil. Title below, in pen ("Vita B. Francisci Patritii Senensis di Tarlati Ordinis Servorum BVM qui obiit 1326-"). Below, in pencil: "193/2/2/0." Pasted on spine: "7380."|Ms. codex.|Title from gilt title on fol. 14r.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 45; 1-410 54 (+1); quires signed a-e on lower right corner of last leaf, verso, of gathering.|Layout: 20 lines per page; ruled in dry point with double lines running length of the page on all sides.|Script: Humanistic book script in one hand.|Decoration: On fol. 1r, full illuminated border of bianchi girari with birds, putti and insects, with pink, green, and blue infilling and gold decorations. Historiated initial (6-line) with profile portrait of Blessed Francesco Patrizi (in habit, holding a book) and in the right border a female bust on blue background, reminiscent of della Robbia. At bottom center, Piccolomini arms, surmounted by bishop's mitre. On fol. 14r, 5-line initial in gold, on full-length border of bianchi girari with pink, blue, and green infilling and pen flourishes; accompanied by 3 lines of illuminated gold capitals.|Binding: Limp vellum binding (wider at top); pastedowns missing; 2 sewn thongs; holes on fore-edge of binding for fasteners. Sewn endbands laced in. Title on spine: "Vita Fran[cis]ci Patri[-]ii Or[dinis] Ser[vorum], Et C[etera]."|Origin: Since the text was written by a Servite friar (cf. "ordinis nostri" on fol. 11r, 12v, 13v), it was probably produced at one of the Servite monasteries in the area of Florence. The dedication to Pius II provides a terminus ante quem of 1464. However, the fact that the arms on fol. 1r are surmounted by a bishop's mitre, rather than the papal tiara, has been interpreted to indicate that the manuscript was written for another Piccolomini, such as Antonio Piccolomini or Franceso Piccolomini, both archbishops of Siena in the third quarter of the 15th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 33.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS uncat 1967 1.11.|1. fol. 1r-14r: "[title, in gold capitals] Ad Pium II P[er] F[ratrem] Paulum in Almi Francisci Senensis Laude Prologi Pri[ncipium]. [text] Quum verear audaciae vel temeritati ad scribenumne sit adolescentem doctissimum virum et nostris temporibus sanctissimum ... Hunc igitur accipias mi[t?]tandum cuius sane donis ['donis' is a later correction] petri navigium incolume ad portum deducas."|2. fol. 14r-45r: "[title, in gold capitals] Almi viri Francisci Senens vita miraculorum fertilis. Ad Pium II directa. [text] Francisco morum modestiae sanctitatisque vitam fertilem prosequor ... Sed cui maiora videndi voluntas est: ad miraculorum volumen senas proficiscatur necesse est ubi nullum infirmitatum genus curatum deficit. Laus deo."

physical_description: Extent: 190 leaves : paper ; 160 x 107 (109-122 x 51-60) mm.
note: Formerly in the library of Isaac Foot; bookplate of Isaac Foot on piece of reinforcing millboard at end of prayer book.|Unbound ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, with watermarks. One watermark consists of 2 crescent moons facing the same direction; not in Bricquet, but there are close parallels from Venice, 1610-1740 A.D. in Heawood, Monumenta Chartae Papyraceae, vol. I, Watermarks, nos. 863-866. Another watermark, also not in Bricquet, occurs on fol. 190 and consists of the name "Andrea " in cursive script. Catchwords at bottom left corner of recto of every page.|Layout: Unruled, 7-11 lines per page. Vowelling in red; some words in red with yellow underlining.|Decoration: Some geometric designs in yellow, red, and light blue (cf. fol. 29v, 30r, 11v).|Binding: Unbound; two loose boards cut to size of the text block, made out of what appears to be millboard, laid on either side of the text block; red leather cover acting as a wrapper, blind tooled and decorated in dark brown, with triangular flap and a long leather thong used to close the wrapper by being wound around the book several times.|Accompanying materials: Bookbag: original bookbag appears to have been mended by an outer bookbag, which has been sewn on and decorated with bright green leather; similar in appearance to a saddle bag or satchel; two circles of green leather on the front of the bag; triangular flap decorated with green leather, blind tooled, with a toggle to attach it to the inner bag's flap; two plaited loops on either side of the outer bag to close the flaps with. "Muḥammad" written on both sides of bookbag.|Origin: Produced in North Africa, perhaps in the 18th century.

physical_description: Extent: 130 leaves : paper ; 219 x 124 (145 x 75) mm. bound to 224 x 123 mm.
note: Presented by L.J. Mackintosh to Thomas Bromfield Ferrers, May 15, 1824; subsequently acquired by the Bancroft Library. Front pastedown: bookplate (with arms) of T.B. Ferrers; above, bookplate of the Bancroft Library. Front free endpaper, verso, 20-line dedicatory poem from L.J. Mackintosh, Guilford Street, to Thomas Bromfield Ferrers, dated 15 May 1824, beginning: "It boots not that I tell thee why I send / To one so fond of ancient lore as thee / A lay of brilliant genius that was penned / In the best days of Roman minstrelsy ..." First flyleaf, recto, in pen, "Oratio manuscrito" and below, in another hand, initials ("[-?] A."). Fol. 2r, in pen, monogram with "h" above, then "Quamvis superbus ambules pecunia[e?] / Fortuna non mutat genus" (Horace Epode IV.5). Back flyleaf, verso, in pencil at top, "0374131x."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, fol. i + i (parchment = original flyleaf) + 130 + ii; 1-1310; catchwords written vertically; watermarks: fol. 129, simple cross on top of an initial; fol. 128, two arrows, crossed, similar to Bricquet 6278, and 6280-6281.|Layout: Fol. 1-80: 25 lines, unruled. Fol. 81-127, 23 lines, unruled. Spaces left for initials which are unexecuted.|Script: 2 scribes: fol. 1-80 in slightly clubbed humanistic bookhand; fol. 81-127 in cursive sloping humanistic bookhand.|Origin: Produced in northeastern Italy in the second half of the 15th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 157.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PA6393.A4 1450z.|1. fol. 3r-65v, Odes: "[M]aecenas atavis aedite [sic] regibus / O et praesidium et dulce decus meum / sunt quos curricula pulverem Olympicum ... Lidiis remisto carmine tybiis / Troyamque et Anchisen et almae / Progeniem veneris canemus."|2. fol. 65v-78v, Epodes: "[I]bis Liburnis inter alta navium / Amice propugnacula / Paratus omne Caesaris periculum ... Desideriique temperare poculum / Plorem artis in te nil agentis exitus."|3. fol. 78v-80r, Carmen saeculare: "[Ph]oebe silvarumque potens Diana / Lucidum caeli decus o colendi / Semper et culti date quae precamur ... Spem bonam certamque domum reporto / Doctus et Phoebi chorus et Dianae / Dicere laudes. Telos."|4. fol. 82r-127r, Satires: "[Q]ui fit Mecenas ut nemo quam sibi sorte / seu non dederit seu fors obiecerit illa ... Ut nihilo omnino gustaremus velut illis / Canidia affl[o?]ret peior serpentibus a[-?]ris. Telōs [sic]."

genre_as_recorded: Manuscripts--Italy--15th century|Illuminated manuscripts--Italy--15th century|Antiphonaries|Choir books|Wooden boards (Binding)|Manuscript waste (Binding)|Brass bosses (Binding)|Centerpiece and cornerpiece bindings (Binding)
subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Liturgy--Texts--Early works to 1800|Divine office (Music)--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Latin--California--Berkeley|Illumination of books and manuscripts, Italian--15th century--Specimens
physical_description: Extent: 151 leaves : parchment, color illustrations, music ; 604 x 421 mm bound to 630 x 443 mm
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 151 + i (paper).|Script: Gothic.|Decoration: 1 illuminated border; 248 illuminated initials; 47 miniatures; illuminator identified as Francesco da Castello (see Overty). Music: Square notation on 4-line red staves.|Binding: 15th century leather over wooden boards with corner and center brass bosses and edges, clasps missing, remnant of red wax seal on front cover, vellum label with "G" nailed on back cover; parchment waste pastedowns from another [unidentified] missal.|Origin: Identified as "Antiphonal 3", part of a set of lavishly illuminated choir books commissioned for the Benedictine monastery of San Sisto in Piacenza, Italy. Consisting of 14 volumes, and containing graduals and antiphoners necessary for the celebration of the mass and the divine office, the set of was used continuously by the monastery over the next 300 years. In the early 19th century, as the French army was poised to enter the city of Piacenza, Benedetto Affaticati, a monk of San Sisto, hid the choir books in the attic of his family's home on the outskirts of the city. In 1864, they were rediscovered and sold to Michele Cavaleri, a well-known collector. Cavaleri then sold them to his friend Enrico Cernuschi, who shipped them to Paris where they remained until his death in 1896. When Cernuschi's heirs sold his collection in 1897 the set of San Sisto choir books was dispersed. See J.F. Overty, "Reconstructing the monastic choir books of San Sisto in Piacenza."|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 59.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS M2150 1480.

physical_description: Extent: 164 leaves : parchment, color illustrations ; 290 x 190 (210 x 150) mm bound to 290 x 200 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 866:6) & positive (BANC MS UCB 73 FILM)
note: A note in Latin in a French hand on the first parchment flyleaf records that the manuscript was purchased on 8 June 1479 by an owner whose name is illegible; Count MacCarthy-Reagh, of Toulouse; bought from the Paris bookseller Royez by Sir Thomas Phillipps, his MS. 4377.|Authorship fictitiously ascribed to Walter Map, a diplomatic and ecclesiastical official of King Henry II of England.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 73.|Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: collation indiscernable; manuscript bound too tightly.|Layout: 40 lines per page; ruled in lead.|Script: Written in a gothic script by one hand.|Decoration: 1 historiated initial on gold ground. 9- and 10- line initials in particolored red and blue with infilling and flourishing of red and blue; 2- and 3-line initials in alternating red and blue with pen-flourishing of the other color.|Straight-grained red morocco, 18th century; gilt border and spine; bound by Richard Wier, approximately 1774.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ1475 G7.|1. fol. 1r-79v: "[text] La veille de la pentecoste quant li compaignon de la table roonde furent venu ... et quant boorz at contees les aventures del graal celes quilles ot veues, si furent mises en escrit et gardes en larmaire de salesbieres, dont mestre Gautier map le trest a fere son livre do S. Graal por amor do roi Henri son segnor qui fist lestoire translater en francois, si se test atant que plus nen dit a ceste foiz des aventures del S. Graal."|2. fol. 80r-163v: "[text] Apres ce que mestre Gautier map ot translate des aventures del Saint Graal assez seffisamment ... si se test ore atant mestre Gautier map de Lancelot et fenist ici son livre si outreement que apres ce nen porroit nus renier qui nen mentist de totes choses. Explicit la mort Artur."

physical_description: Extent: 103 leaves : paper ; 296 x 213 (164-230 x 110-170) mm bound to 302 x 219 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 729:5) & positive (BANC MS UCB 85 FILM)|Extent: 23 leaves : paper ; 296 x 213 (164-230 x 110-170) mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 1704) & positive (BANC MS UCB 145 FILM)
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from modern inscription on front pastedown.|Collation: Paper (among identified watermarks: Briquet's "Fleur de lys," 7111; "Coutelas," 5128-5134; "Croix grecques," 5439; "Monts," 11667-11677; "Huchet, " 7645; "Basilic," 2628-2682; "Cercle," 3194; "Arbalète," 762-763), fol. i + 103 (traces of foliation on recto in top right corner, or, occasionally, on the verso, top left corner); 112 (with 7 loose leaves and 2 bifolia inserted) 212 ( -1), 32 ( -1), 46 512 ( -1) 612 712 ( -1) 82 9 (made up of 7 loose folios) 104 1112 1212 ( -1) 134; catchwords on fol. 32v, 50v, 62v. Additions (MS UCB 145): Paper (Briquet "Monts," 11667-11677; "Huchet," 7669), fol. 23; 1 quire of 8 leaves plus 15 loose leaves; no catchwords present.|Layout: Primarily in long lines, although fol. 1r-7r and 17r-21r are in 2 columns; 37-50 lines per page; 1st quire ruled in red.|Script: Written mainly in gothic script, although humanistic book script is also present. 5 hands identified. Scribe 1, fol. 1r-7ra, 17ra-21ra; scribe 2, fol. 8r-15r; scribe 3, fol. 22r-72v, 74r-82r, 88r-103v; scribe 4, fol. 73r-v; scribe 5, fol. 82v-84v.|Decoration: Spaces reserved for initials; numerous manicules (often with extremely elongated and twisted fingers) and other marginal finding aids, sometimes in the shape of animals (e.g., an octopus, fol. 1v, and a snake, fol. 18v).|Binding: Modern paper over limp pasteboards; 2 raised bands laced in.|Origin: Likely written in northern Italy, perhaps the Veneto region, judging from the watermarks, as well as from the presence of certain characteristic linguistic tendencies in the text and in Italian marginal notes.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 85.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS AC13 C5.|Includes Paradoxa and Somnium Scipionis, by Cicero; De maganimitate, by Seneca; Epistola Domini, by Petrarch; Epistola Magistri Petri de Parma; Preambulum, sive, Introductio libri Lucani editum per Magistri Petrum de Parma; Prohemium ad Boetii de consolatione; Liber de mirabilibus Romae; and other unidentified texts. UCB 145 was originally part of this ms.; includes Prohemium Valerii Maximi, by Benvenutus de Imola; Prohemium Statii compilatum, by Petrus of Caneffigi; De nugis curialium, by Walter Map; and other texts. Codex composed of loose quires and folios; beginning and ending incomplete. For a thorough description (contents and physical composition), see Carlo Maria Monti, "Il codice Berkeley, Bancroft Library, f2MS AC13 C5," in Italia medioevale e umanistica, XII (1979), 396-411.

collation beginning at fol. 1: 18 (+1, fol. 1) 2-58 68 (-5 and 8, formerly fol. 45, 48) 78 (-8, formerly fol. 56) 88 98 (-5 through 8, formerly fol. 69-72) 108 (-1 through 4, formerly fol. 73-76) 118 (-4 and 5, formerly fol. 84-85) 128 (-5 through 7, formerly fol. 93-95) 138 (but with first leaf, fol. 97, now bound between fol. 103-104) 148 (-3 through 6, formerly fol. 107-110) 15-178 188 (-1, formerly fol. 137) 194 (added quire, unfoliated) 208 (-5 through 8, after fol. 148) 214 (added quire, foliated 149-152) 226 (-1 and 2, formerly fol. 153-154; + fol. 158, added paper leaf); catchwords in center lower margin in script of text.|Layout: 6 lines of text and music.|Script: Written mainly in one heavily gothicizing hand but with several humanistic hands present; later hands range from rough noting scripts to simple round roman miniscules based on printing fonts.|Decoration: Opening initial, fol. 1 (leaf intruded from another ms.): 90 x 85 mm.; archaically styled initial based on French models of mid-15th cent. in white patterned red and blue, flanked by tall, green "dragon" infilled with tendrils of colored flowers and tri-lobed leaves, the whole placed on a cusped burnished gold ground with a floral border in similar style the length of text; opening initial fol. 2: 140 x 110 mm., blue with simple void design on squared ground of regular red penwork tendril, each flower of which with pale, green center, and with simple red penwork flourishing the length of text; secondary initials 1-line of text and music, in cadel style, touched in yellow wash, sometimes incorporating a profile; rubrics in red throughout; frequent flourishings in the shape of a leaf at the end of the last line of a page; space between syllables in text filled by a thick red line.|Music: Square notation in red 5-line staves; 6 lines of text and music per page.|Binding: 16th cent. leather over heavy wooden boards; original leather appears tooled or stamped with some ruling and some curling rolls in lozenge pattern; cover repaired repeatedly by nailing strips of leather of spine; evidence of one fore-edge clasp closing on front cover.|Origin: Written during 16th cent., possibly in Spain; probably for use in a Franciscan convent, given the mass of Francis (fol. 42-43), and certainly in Franciscan use by the time later notes and leaves were added.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 158.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS M2150 1500z.

physical_description: Extent: 182 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 145 x 102 (112-117 x 74) mm. bound to 153 x 101 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 669:13) & positive (BANC MS UCB 94 FILM)
note: Produced in the diocese of Trier, as indicated by the saints included in the calendar; later perhaps in possession of a Franciscan congregation (cf. addition of St. Francis to the calendar in a later hand, fol. 6r. Documentation in file states that Dominic also added to calendar in a 13th cent. hand; unable to verify). In library of Dr. Leander van Ess of Darmstadt (1772-1847), then of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 430). Pasted onto front: "Van Ess". On spine: "45" pasted on; below that: "430". Fol. 2r: bookstamp of Thomas Phillips with no. 430 below. Written in ink on top of fol. 182r (= back paste-down): "Professor van Ess zum Marburg." "Number 26" pasted onto back paste-down.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 182 (fol. 1 forms front paste-down and fol. 182 is back paste-down); 18 ( -1) 2-45 5-158 168 ( -fol. ripped out) 17-228 238 ( -1) 248 ( -1).|Layout: 19 lines per page, line ruling in both ink and dry point; double ruling on outer edges; horizontal lines run all the way across the page.|Script: Gothic script in several hands.|Decoration: 3 full-page illuminated miniatures on gold ground, framed with borders of red, green, yellow and silver: the Annunciation (fol. 7v), God the Father (fol. 8r), King David (fol. 8v). 1 full-page initial on fol. 9v, in gold and silver with foliate decoration, rubbed. 6-11 line initials in red on gold or silver ground; some illegible due to rubbing. 3-line initials in red, some decorated with green.|Music: Fol. 180v-181r.|Binding: Full leather binding, blind-tooled over wooden boards, spine disintegrating; 3 sewn bands with end bands sewn in, fore-edge clasp missing, fore-edge finding marks made of string.|Origin: Calendar indicates that psalter produced in the diocese of Trier in mid-12th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 94.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2033 A2 1150.|1. fol. 1v-7r: Calendar.|3. fol. 9r-155r, Psalter: "In principio erat verbum [rubr.] S. Johannes [text] et verbum erat apud deum ... Beatus vir qui non abiit in consilio impiorum ... Laudate eum in cymbalis bene sonantibus laudate eum in cymbalis iubilationis omnis spiritus laudet dominum."|4. fol. 155v-170v, Canticles, Lord's Prayer, Creeds. fol. 155v: "Confitebor tibi domine quoniam iratus es mihi ... Ego dixi in dimidio die ..." fol. 157r: "Exultavit cor meum in domino et exultatum est cornu meum in domino meo ..." fol. 157v: "Cantemus domino gloriose enim honorificatus est ..." fol. 159r: "Domine audivi auditio[nem] tuam et timui ..." fol. 161r: "Audite celi que loquor audiat terra verba oris mei ..." fol. 164v: "Benedicite omnia opera domini domino laudate et superexaltate eum in secula ..." fol. 165v: "[rubr.] Angelicus ymnus [text] Te dominum laudamus te dominum confitemur ..." fol. 166v: "Benedictus dominus deus Israhel quia visitavit ..." fol. 167r: "Magnificat anima mea dominum et exultavit spiritus meus in deo salutari meo ..." fol. 167v: "[rubr.] Cant. Symeoni [text] Nunc dimittis tuum domine secundum verbum tuum in pace ... Pater noster qui es in celis sanctificetur nomen tuum ..." fol. 168r: "Credo in dominum patrem omnipotente Creatorem celi et terre ..." fol. 168v: "Quicumque vult salvus esse ante omnia opus est ut teneat catholicam fidem ..." fol. 170v: "Hec est fides catholica quam nisi quisque fideliter firmiter crediderit salvus esse non poterit."|7. fol. 180v-181r: Music.|8. fol. 181r: "Placebo domino in regione vivorum ... Tuam dominus deposcimus pietatem ut eis tribuere digneris lucidas et quietas mansiones."|10. fol. 182r: back pastedown from a Biblical commentary on Tobias 12.

note: From the library of Alessandro Pado[v]ani, a 17th cent. physician of Forli (ownership note on fol. 1). In the 18th cent. the manuscript passed into the library of the Locatelli of Bergamo, and then into the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 9592) in 1836. On front pastedown, in pencil: "Bartholomou ." On flyleaf, recto: "No. 43" in pen and "No. 513" in pencil; also in pencil: "Payne 1826." On fol. 1r, in pen at bottom: "Di Aless[and]ro Padoani[-]." Below, in another hand, in ink: "N 43." On spine: the arms of the Locatelli.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 72 + i; visible watermarks on front pastedown and rear flyleaf; 110 216 38( -3) 412 58 (+2) 66 78(+fol. 61, octavo size) 84(+1); parchment is of low quality, with many holes and flaws; medieval foliation on fol. 1-53; fol. 10 bound after fol. 11; fol. 28 and 29 removed; 2 folia (between fol. 31 and fol 32, and between fol. 38 and fol. 39) unnumbered; fol. 54-72 have modern foliation only.|Layout: Lines variable (32-41 lines per page); ruled in dry point with lines running length of page; prickings sometimes visible.|Script: Gothic script; at least 4 hands (all Italian).|Decoration: 1-3 line initials in red or occasionally blue; marginal drawing on fol. 15v.|Binding: Bound in green three-quarter roan over pasteboards with laces sewn in; title in gold in spine on morrocco title-label, "Angli de Propr. rerum m.ss. Num. 43" over arms of Locatelli family (an owl and three stars).|Origin: Produced in Italy in the 13th cent. in a university town, probably Bologna.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 95.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS B765.G95P5.|1. fol. 1r-27v, Philosophia: "Potissimum universorum expetendorum est sapientia, per quam perfecta omnium bonorum acquiritur forma ... ut animus lectoris ad cetera discenda accedat, hic iiii particule longitudinem terminemus."|2. fol. 28r-53v, Didascalicon: "Tribus modis res subsistare habent: in actu, in intellectu in mente divina hoc est in ratione divina ... [rubr] Didascalicon Ugonis de studio legendi. Liber i. de origine artis incipit. [text] Omnium expetendorum prima est sapientia in qua perfecti boni forma consistit ... Rogemus igitur nunc sapientiam ut radiare dignetur in cordibus nostris et illuminare nobis in semitis suis ut introducat vos ad puram et sine animalibus cenam. Explicit Didascalicon Ugonis."|3. fol. 54r-59v: "[a florilegium of patristic texts on the souls of the just in hell] "Quis mihi tribuat ut in inferno protegas me? ... ubi plus in nobis valet fides qua credimus qua rerum corporalium species quam per oculos cernimus corporales."|4. fol. 60r-66r: "[commentary on Ovid's Heroides] "Pubplius Ovidius Naso romanus fuit, qui quodam tempore romanorum iuvenum inpulsus ... est descriptor veri maris."|5. fol. 66r-68v: "[commentary on the life of Virgil and the Aeneid, Books I-V] Gemmine doctrine observationem perpendimus Maronem in sua Eneide habuisse ... Itaque sensum multiformem et rationi contrapositum intelligimus per Irim multicolorem."|7. fol. 73v: Notes.

physical_description: Extent: 54 leaves : parchment ; 223 x 165 (156-159 x 109-113) mm. bound to 230 x 166 mm.
note: Belonged in the 15th cent. to one Bardo, who used the volume as security for a loan of 12 solidi from Bernardino Driezo, according a ricordo on fol.54v. Passed from the library of Bernard Rosenthal to the Bancroft Library. Reverse front cover: "207 Registrato di Carta 54: senza le due Manoscritte de' Riguardi" (in ink); below that, in ink, "54 feuillets." Fol. iir: In several places: "Iste liber est mei Bartolomei Tesbaldis " In another hand, several times: "Martinus." In a third hand: "Antonius." On the same page, medieval handwritten monogram, perhaps with the letters VIAMLSVA . Also a round 19th cent. ownership stamp, with the initials F T K. Fol. 49r: Ownership note, only partially legible, possibly in Spanish: "Agnu d [-------]S. Antonius de Padua [----------]esto meo libro " Fol. 54v: "Ricordo come mi bardo debeo ..." And below: "Iste liber est mei bardi qui nomine vacor Et de boateriis [crossed out] sanguinitate dicor." Penultimate fol. v: "Iacobus d[?--] rectore " In another hand: "Martinus." In another hand: "bartolomen[-?] Fibaldm " On reverse of back cover, in ink: "por."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: ii (i=18th cent. paper with visible watermark; ii=original flyleaf) + 54 + ii (original flyleaf made from 18th cent. paper with a different watermark + flyleaf from another manuscript); 1-58 68 (with stub visible after fol. 48); catchwords in bottom center.|Layout: 24 lines to a page; ruled in lead, with vertical lines running all the way down the page. Prickings visible. Foliation: fol. 1-10: later foliation in ink in arabic numerals; fol. 11-54: modern foliation in pencil in arabic numerals over earlier foliation in ink in roman numerals (often almost completely rubbed out).|Script: Rounded gothic minuscule (14th cent.), with initials and incipits in red. Cursive script on fol. iiv.|Binding: 18th cent. vellum. Original binding included: 2 parchment leaves from a 14th cent. grammar, possibly Donatus, now preserved within 18th cent. binding.|Origin: Produced in Italy in the 14th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 100.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS uncat 1967 5.13.|1. fol. 1r-54v, De consolatione philosophiae: "Carmina qui quondam studio florenit peregi Flebilis heu mestos cogor inire modos Ecce michi lacere dictant scribenda camene ... Aversamini igitur vitia colite virtutes ad rectam spem animam sublevate humiles preces in excelsa porrigite. Magna vobis est si dissimulare non vultis necessitas indicta probitatis. Cum ante oculos agitis iudicis cuncta cernentis. Amen."|2. fol i recto and penultimate fol. recto-verso: pages from a grammar, probably that of Donatus.

Pourquoy concludz que qui fidellement / Vivra pour vray, fera ben fynnement / Ainsi quom peult juger par ceste histore [sic] / La bonne fin rend la parfaicte glore." fol. 40r-v ruled but blank.

physical_description: Extent: 70 leaves : paper ; 304 x 200 (255 x 142) mm. bound to 309 x 210 mm.
note: In the library of the Collegio Mayor de Cuenca in the 18th century; passed into the library of Frank Kissner. Front pastedown, bookplate of the Bancroft Library. Front free endpaper, in pencil, "L8683." Fol. i, recto, in pen, "[-]oe ." Fol. i, verso, in pen, shelfmark "No. 94" and below in same hand, "De la Bibliotheca del Collegio Mayor de Cuenca." Back of free endpaper, in pencil at top, "10055" and at bottom of page, "CWKG" and "w/ ref" and "KISS120."|Ms. codex.|Title from title pages (fols. 1r and 54r).|Collation: Paper, fol. i (modern endpaper) + iii + 72 + i (modern endpaper); too tightly bound to analyze collation; catchwords on verso of nearly every fol. from 2v to 52v. Watermarks: on fol. I, three circles arranged on same line, top with cross inside, middle with initials ("BD"?), third with lower-case I ; similar to Briquet 3245; fol. 70, another watermark, again with three circles arranged on same line, top with W inside; second with initials ("VC"?) inside; third with Greek cross inside; below, facing down, crown.|Layout: Fol. 1r-55r: 20-22 lines per page, with single outer bounding line ruled in hard point; fol. 55v-70r: 22 lines, ruled with vertical bounding lines in hard point, written in 1 column (257 x 118 mm.).|Script: Cursive; 3 hands.|Binding: Mottled 18th cent. calf, blind tooled border; gilt decoration and title on spine ("Discu [-]ont bruj"); mottled endpapers.|Origin: Produced in "Madrid a 20 de Abril de 1611 años."|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, fMS UCB 154.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BF1584.S7.V2 1611.|1. fol. 1r-53v: "[heading] Discurso cerca de los cuentos de las brujas. Escrito por Pedro de Valencia. Dirigado al Ill[ustrísi]mo sénor Don Bernardo de Sandoval y Rojas, Cardenal Arcobispo de Toledo, Inquisidor General de España [text] Aviendo leido un papel impreso, que contenia del Auto de la fé ultimo, que se celebró en Logroño para castigo de algunos herejes ... suplico a V[ue] S[eñoria] I[lustrísima] se sirva de verlo todo, y mandar, si parecieve conveniente, lo vea el Consejo, a cuya censura tambien lo someto. Dios guarde la persona de V[ue] S[eñoria] Ill[trísi]mo en Madrid a 20 Abril de 1611 años."|2. fol. 54r-70r: "[heading] Suma de las relaciones de Logroño a cerca de las brujas [text] Prestó me un cavallero las relaciones del auto ultimo de la fé, que se celebró en Logroño pidiendo se las boluiesse presto ... Puede serque el pacto sea entre ellos y que esten de acuend[o?] de conferar siempre tales cosas antesque lo ciento, pues se conforman tanto y este mod[o?] de entender no excluye los beneficias o beneficos ni las unciones para dormir y soñar esto mi parece salvo etcétera et sub correctione santae ecclesiae Romanae."

note: Ms. leaf.|Beginning of the first epistle of St. John, with attribution to the Blessed Sargis Shnorhali Vardapet.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, single sheet.|Layout: Fol. 1r written in single column, 2 lines of majuscule script, 10 lines of miniscule bolorgir; fol. 1v written in 2 columns of 35 lines, miniscule bolorgir.|Script: Written in bolorgir script by one hand. Later annotations at foot of fol. 1r, likely fountain pen ink; repetition of first two lines of text.|Decoration: Recto of leaf (beginning of epistle) has ornate, intricate decoration with geometric and floral motifs, which occupies the top half of the leaf; other illustrations are marginal ornaments and depictions of birds; all decoration is characterized by bright colors including orange, magenta, blue, purple, and pink, with generous application of gold. Initial of the opening line is formed by an animal supporting the bottom corner of the geometric design.|Origin: Stylistically, the illuminations are closely similar to those in the Gladzor Gospels (created 1300-1307), which were painted in two locations: the scriptorium of Elegis or Noravankʻ and the monastery of Gladzor. However, this style is also present in manuscripts produced at other locations.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 289.

physical_description: Extent: 136 parchment ; 224 x 150 (182 x 95) mm bound to 237 x 163 mm
note: Formerly in possession of Joseph Martini (catalogue 27, no. 2), who falsely attributed it to have been in the library of Paolo Giovio of Como (1483-1552); likely from the library of Francesco Giovio instead -- see Ferrari, M. "Dopo Bernardo: biblioteche e 'scriptoria' cisterciensi dell'Italia settentrionale nel XII secolo. In San Bernardo e l'Italia, [253]-306. Bequest of James K. Moffitt to The Bancroft Library|Ms. composite codex.|Title from modern inscription on front pastedown.|Collation: [Aquinas, Sermones] Parchment, fol. i + 29; 1-38 46 (+1) 5-108; catchwords at the end of each quire. [Unidentified ms.] Parchment, fol. 57; 1-212 48 512; catchwords at the end of each quire. Both mss. numbered by openings with letters, often cropped; at the head of each column of test, so the facing pages from left to right read, for example, "31a" and "31b"; the added ms. at the end is laid out in 2 columns per page, so the openings read, for example "39 a b" and "39 c d."|Layout: [Aquinas, Sermones] 35 long lines; frame-ruled in lead; prickings visible. [Unidentified ms.] 2 columns; 31-38 lines; frame-ruled in lead, prickings visible.|Script: Both texts written in gothic minuscule, each by one hand.|Decoration: Aquinas, Sermones: 3-line red initials, sometimes with simple flourishing; 1-line initials within text slashed in red. Unidentified ms.: 2-line initials in red or in black with red flourishing.|Binding: 17th cent. binding in brown sheepskin over pasteboard; blind tooling around edges; 3 raised bands; sewn end-bands laced in; contiguous endsheet and pastedown.|Origin: Aquinas, Sermones probably written in the Cistercian monastery of S. Maria of Morimondo in Milan by commission and at the expense of the monk Beltramo dei Redoldi, as declared by his note at the end of the text (fol. 79v). The second, unidentified text is written in a similar script, is similarly frame-ruled, and displays the same openings at the head of each page (see collation note), and thus (presumably) has a similar origin.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 4.|Former shelfmark: MAR 26.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS B765.T5S3.|2. fol. 80r-636r: "[unidentified ms. (incomplete): text] ... celo cum quibus gaudendum est de istis omnibus ... propter habundantiam eternalem habunda cum Paulo ... ex parte cause efficitis quando ... auctor ... ex parte cause materali quando ..."

physical_description: Extent: 259 parchment ; 314 x 218 (199 x 119) mm bound to 328 x 222 mm|Extent: 1 negative (Box 760:1) & positive (BANC MS UCB 9 FILM)
note: Originally in the library of Giovannella Caracciolo; later property of George Folliott; passed into library of James K. Moffitt. On front pastedown: armorial bookplate of George Folliott; bookplate of James K. Moffitt; bookplate of Pauline Fore Moffitt Library, University of California, Berkeley. In ink on second flyleaf: "MS. on Vellum in the Gothic character; with 30 small miniatures, and all Initials illuminated." Pressmark in ink, on lower right hand corner of back free endpaper: "A. VI 5." In 16th cent. hand in bottom margin of fol. 49r: "INRI Re iudeorum."|Ms. codex.|Title from rubric (fol. 100r).|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii (modern parchment) + 259 + ii (modern parchment); 1-310 410 (fol. 4-6 bound in reverse order; should be read 34, 36, 35, 37) 5-1410 1510 (second bifolium of quire 15 bound in reversed position with early modern tie marks directing reader: fol. 151, 159, 153-158, 152, 160) 16-2510 2610 (fol. 10 missing); catchwords vertically along inner bounding line.|Layout: Written in 34 long lines ruled in ink; frame-ruled.|Script: Written in a round Italian gothic book hand by Andreuccio della Monaca.|Decoration: 30 historiated initials by Cola Rapicano, usually 11-line in blue, maroon and green acanthus on gold ground. 13-line initial on fol. 1 shows Paul the hermit in front of his cave, weaving a basket. Secondary 4-line capitals in gold on blue and red ground. Rubrics in red except for fol. 1, which has 6 lines of rubrics in gold square capitals. Offset of a full decorated border (originally fol. 1 recto) still visible on fol. 1 verso; the original center illumination was probably the Caracciolo coat of arms.|Binding: 19th century blind-tooled blue morocco with gilt fillet and gilt edges.|Origin: Written in Naples between 5 Nov. 1473 and 1 Apr. 1474 by Andreuccio della Monaca of Cava dei Tirreni, and illuminated by Cola Rapaicano, as a gift from the Aragonese court in Naples to Giovannella Caracciolo, Duchess of Termoli, daughter of Giacomo Caracciolo (the chancellor of the realm), and a mistress of King Ferrante I of Naples.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, fMS UCB 9.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BR1705.A2H6.|Former shelfmark: MAR 40.

Diocese of Salisbury (England)|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Manuscrits latins médiévaux et modernes--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscrits médiévaux--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 493 leaves : parchment ; 168 x 113 (108-111 x 75) mm. bound to 175 x 118 mm.
note: Manuscript associated with the diocese of Salisbury in the 15th century. Later belonged to the library of W. Creswell; then in 1913 to that of John Meade Falkner; subsequently passed into the library of James K. Moffitt. On front pastedown: bookplate of James K. Moffitt; below, bookplate of Pauline Fore Moffitt Library. On first free endpaper, in ink, "W. Creswell. Iohannis M. Falkner d[ono] d[edit] d[edicavit] longae Amiciti[e?], [------------?] et aurei to[-]g[---], haud im[--] [----] mcmxiii." Fol. 4r: erased ownership note at foot of column 1 (and also fol. 493r, bottom col. 2, another erasure)|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (modern parchment) + iii (parchment) + 493 + viii (parchment) + i (modern parchment); 1-320 414 (+1) 5-616 7-820 910 10-1216 1314 (+1) 14-2316 2424 25-2916 309.|Layout: Fol. 1r-458v: 2 columns, 44-47 lines, ruled in ink. Fol. 459r-493r: 3 columns (written space 116 x 84 mm.), 46 lines, ruled in ink with double margins for capitals. Prickings visible.|Script: Gothic in at least 3 hands.|Decoration: 64 large painted initials, some extending full length of page, in blue and red, with grotesques. Page titles, chapter numerals and 5- and 2-line initials in red and blue with pen line ornamentation.|Binding: Modern olive morocco binding with gilt tooling by Waters Newcastle. Title on spine: "Biblia Latina."|Accompanying materials: Three letters of the medievalist Christopher Wordsworth to John Meade Falkner (10 Feb., 24 Feb., and 12 Apr. 1916) concerning the epigrams of the 15th century bishops of Salisbury on fol. 500r. Also two photographs, and one sheet of transcriptions of fol. 500r.|Origin: Produced in England, perhaps Reading (see letter of S. Sussman, 9 July 1963, who suggests 14th century date). Epigrams on fol. 500r produced in 15th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 12.|Former shelfmark: MAR 28.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS75 1350.|3. fol. 1r-4r, col. 1, Jerome's prologue: "[rubr.] Hic incipit [rest of rubric largely illegible due to repair of fol. 1] [text] Frater Ambrosius mihi tua munuscula perferens detulit ... et a Benesi exordium carpere orationibus iuves quo possim eodem spirtu quo scripti sunt libri, in Latinum eas transferre sermonem [erased ownership note]. Incipit liber Geneseos."|4. fol. 4r, col. 2-fol. 458v: "In principio creavit Deus celum et terram. ... Veni Domine Iesu Amen. Gratia domini nostri Iesu Christi cum nobis. Amen [rubr.] Explicit Apochalipsis. Incipiunt interpretationes Hebraicorum nominum per a litteram."|6. fol. 500r, Epigrams of Salisbury bishops: "Cordificis natus pastor Sarum titulatus ... Gratia divina liberaberis a libitina."

physical_description: Extent: 1 volume ([511] leaves) : paper ; 30 x 23 cm.
note: In black ink; various hands and scripts. Text on both sides of leaves. Title within black ink drawing of a frontal architectural structure comprised of two columns in the classic style, decorated with two coats of arms, one of which is illuminated with blue, red, violet, and ochre ink. Various sequences of page numbering, sometimes inconsistent and erroneous. Fourteen leaves removed between ff. [493] and [494]. physical_description: Extent: 1 volume (124 leaves) : parchment ; 20 x 14 cm bound to 21 x 14 cm
note: Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) 124 + i (paper); 12 26 3-48 58(±5,6) 68 76 88(±5,6, -7,8) 98 108(±7,8) 118 128(±2,3) 13-148 15-204. Foliation in pencil: leaves 3-32 foliated 1-31, leaves 33-123 foliated 22-114, leaf 124 foliated 116.|Layout: Written in long lines of 20; frame-ruled in light red ink.|Script: Written in a hybrida formata in two hands; the first hand shows influence from humanist scripts, the second, later hand is rather clumsy and appears only on inserted leaves in quires 5 and 12.|Decoration: Illuminated initials throughout, many decorated with botanical images; full page illustrations on leaf [2]v and leaf 47r of SS. Peter and Paul; half-page illustration on leaf 24v of the Annunciation. Miniatures, apparently added contemporaneously to the illustration of Peter and Paul, depicting John (fol. 8r), Luke (fol. 9r), Matthew (fol. 10r), Mark (fol. 11r), Golgotha (fol. 11v), the Virgin and child (fol. 18v), the Visitation (fol. 23r, that is 32r), the Nativity (fol. 33r, that is 42r), the Annunciation (fol. 37, that is 46r), Jesus (fol. 48r, that is 57r), David (fol. 59r, that is 68r), a skull (fol. 72r that is 81r), and St. Anne (fol. 112r, that is 121r). Margins undecorated.|Origin: Likely written in southern France during the late fifteenth century, with illuminations and some leaves added in the late sixteenth or early seventeenth century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 302.

author_as_recorded: Cofradía de la Caridad de Maqueda (Spain)
physical_description: Extent: 18 leaves : parchment ; 210 x 150 mm, bound to 216 x 161 mm
note: Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. 18 (foliated in modern pencil in arabic numerals in upper right corner); 18 28(-2; 8+1) 32; vertical catchwords.|Layout: Written on up to 24 lines; ruled in brown ink.|Script: Written in brown ink in a gothic rounded hand; added paragraph in cursive script with witness signatures on fol. 18r.|Decoration: Opening initial in red 4-lines high with purple filigree penwork, 38 similar smaller initials introducing each chapter; rubrics in red, a few crosses in red used as word separators.|Binding: Contemporary (second half of the 16th century?) brown calf over wooden boards, sides gilt with four smaller tools, smooth spine with gilt fleurons, two fore-edge clasps and catches.|Origin: Copied, decorated, and bound in Spain. The manuscript was evidently copied in Maqueda, located within the autonomous community of Castilla-La Mancha and the province of Toledo. Although these ordinances were likely copied in the first quarter of the 16th century, the actual text was composed and promulgated in 1493 as stated in the prologue: "An[n]o del nascime[n]to de n[uest]ro rede[m]ptor ih[es]u [christ]o de mill y quatrocie[n]tos y noue[n]ta y tres ... [1493]" (fol. 2v).|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 184.

(Sotheby catalog, 30 November 1965, p. 16). Also on fol. 1r:" A13" (catalog number in Abbey library in 16th cent.) in ink on table of contents; "3 68" in ink in modern hand below table of contents. On spine: "5" pasted on (van Ess numbering); "3 68" written in ink below; below that "391" pasted on (Phillips numbering)|Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubric (fol. 1v).|Collation: Parchment, i (former pastedown, now loose) + 92 leaves (fol. 92 now pastedown); 1-98 106 118 126 (last fol. is pastedown); quires lettered in modern pencil in lower right hand corner on first folio of quire.|Layout: Written in two columns of 38 lines, above the line. Ruled in dry point with double bounding lines. Prickings visible.|Script: Gothic script in several hands. Fol. 1v-89r in rounded gothic script (11th cent.), incipits in rustic capitals. Fol. 89v-90r and 91v-92v in 2nd hand, 12th cent., gothic script. Fol. 90v-91r in a 3rd hand, also 12th cent., gothic script. Short notes on fol. 89r in 2 other hands; one gothic, one a transitional script. Table of contents (fol. 1r) in 15th hand, gothic script.|Decoration: Primary initials (18 lines on fol. 52r; others are 9-10 lines) in red, some with yellow infilling, with interlaced and foliate ornament. Secondary initials (6-7 lines) in red with interlaced decoration; 1-line initials in red within text.|Binding: Light brown doeskin, decorated in blind tooling, over wooden boards. Bound with thongs (in three bands) pegged in. Two fore-edge clasps missing. Front paste-down from an Antiphonal (12th cent.). Leather tags glued onto folios on which new works begin as page markers. Possibly present binding dates to the abbacy of Johannes Rode (d. 1439).|Origin: Produced at the Benedictine abbey of St. Matthias in Trier in the second half of the 11th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 17.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS1235.H5Q2.

title_as_recorded: Ordinances and records of the Cofradía del Señor San Pedro Apóstel of Valdeosera
subject_as_recorded: Cofradía del Señor San Pedro Apóstel (Valdeosera, Spain)--History--Early works to 1800|Catholic Church--Spain--La Rioja--History--Early works to 1800|Église catholique--Histoire--Ouvrages avant 1800|Catholic Church|Confraternities--Spain--La Rioja--History--Early works to 1800|Manuscripts, Spanish--California--Berkeley|Confréries--Espagne--La Rioja--Histoire--Ouvrages avant 1800|Confraternities|Manuscripts, Spanish|California--Berkeley|Spain--La Rioja
author_as_recorded: Cofradía del Señor San Pedro Apóstel (Valdeosera, Spain)
physical_description: Extent: 83 leaves : paper ; 191 x 143 mm, bound to 196 x 145 mm
note: Several names have been inscribed on the inside of the rear cover in 18th- or 19th-century hands, including "Nicasia Rubio Moreno" and Jose Benito Moreno, Cura Economo de la Villa de Baldeosera," who has dated his inscription "año 1835," suggesting the manuscript staying in Valdeosera at least until this year.|Ms. composite codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Paper (similar to Briquet "Main" nos. 10917 (Bordeaux, 1553) or 10922 (1575), and Briquet "Main" no. 11292 (Perpignan, 1552, Ancenis, 1559, Nantes, 1561, Spain, 1560), and Briquet "Main" no. 11302 (Carcassonne, 1596)), fol. viii (parchment) + iii + 72 (foliated in contemporary Arabic numerals in upper right corner: 1-64, 66-73); 18 22 320 ( -320) 420 522 612|Script: Fol. 1v-8v in mostly long lines in a careful semihybrida script, with chapter openings in a larger calligraphic gothic script with some decorative penwork extensions on the opening letters, with words or phrases in the scribe's hand in the lower margin identifying the chapter's subject matter; additions on fol. 8v in two semihybrida hands and one elongated gothic hand. Fol. 9r-83v in mostly long lines (with an informal two-column format adopted on fol. 11r-77v, 79v-81v) in a number of 16th-, 17th-, and 18th-century cursive hands, with additions made to margins and blank leaves in a number of hands of the same period.|Binding: 16th-century limp vellum, with front cover stitched to rear cover along the rear edge of spine, traces of original ties on the inside of rear cover, blue cloth tie now attached to the fore-edge of rear cover, quires have been stitched together along the top and bottom, stitched to the binding through an upper support of leather and a lower support of vellum, both on the outside of spine; inscription in ink on front cover: "San Pedro"; inscriptions in various hands visible on the inside of front and rear covers|Origin: Produced in northern Spain in the province of La Rioja in the 16th-18th centuries. Manuscript assembled from three discrete booklets, all copied in Spain. The parchment booklet, containing the Rule of the Confraternity of San Pedro, was probably copied circa 1557-1558 or shortly thereafter. The second booklet, which contains a confirmation of the Rule issued in 1569, was also probably copied around the same time. The third booklet was certainly produced in Valdeosera, and used for texts added by various members of the confraternity throughout the 17th century and into the early 18th century. The earliest date noted within this booklet is 1609, while the latest is 1726. The watermarks suggest that this booklet was probably assembled around the same time that the second booklet was copied, and was intentionally left blank to allow for added texts.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 242.

physical_description: Extent: 124 leaves : paper, ill., 6 maps ; 206 x 149 (151 x 105-110) mm bound to 215 x 152 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 1056:7) & positive (BANC MS UCB 45 FILM)
note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. i recto).|Collation: Paper, fol. iii + 124 (foliated i-viii and 1-116) + i (modern endsheet); 18 28(+2 pasted in?) 312( -1) 414(+1?) 58 6-98 102 1110 1212 (with bifolium pasted in) 1314.|Layout: 23 lines per page; most pages unruled, some frame-ruled in ink: fol. 3r ruled 151 x 112; fol. 9r ruled 151 x 103; fol. 32r ruled 165 x 103.|Script: Fol. i-111v in humanistic cursive book script, except for "Argumento" (fol. 1r-2r) in humanistic gothic script; fol. 112r-115r in second hand, also humanistic cursive.|Decoration: Frontispiece within a cartouche on fol. i; title page of each book illustrated with pen-and-ink titles (fol. 55v, coat of arms; fol. 23r, man holding scroll; fol. 81r, prince and soldier with scrolls; fol. 96r, nobles on horseback). Additional pen and ink illustrations: coats of arms, fol. 28r, 43v, 44v, and 49v; the liberal arts, fol. 26v. Maps: half-page maps fol. 2r, 3r, 21v; 2-page maps fol. 34v-35r, 79v-80r, 94v-95r. 2-line capitals with flourishes and infilling.|Binding: Modern leather calf binding; decorative horizontal gold tooling on spine.|Origin: Completed October 12, 1550 in Treviso: "Il giorno duodecimo de ottubre del 1550 in Trevigi. [author's signature follows; monogram is difficult to decipher] Il vostro [-]lin[-]sens[-] sc[-]fse" (fol. iiv).|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 45.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS DG975.T807.|2. fol. iii recto-viii verso: "Tavola [first entry] Argumento c [page number] 1 Sito de Trevigi primo c 2 ... Le famegli ch'furno fatte del numero de nobelli dalli magnifici rettori de Trevigi c 109 capitolo 13."|3. fol. 1r-2r: "[rubr.] Argumento [text] Era passato la creatione del mondo mille ducento et sei nella terza eta del mondo successe le guerra troyana ... insegnio che quella citta havea li termini delli loro territorii alle torre nominate cosi hebbe principio la prima fabricha sopra il terreno trivisiano fatto per la gente troyana."|4. fol. 2v-22r, Book 1: "Essendo principiata l'attore con la damisella sopra con li Trevisi si a populo atorno la torre molte habitatione et fu apreso il Sile in locho eminente chiamato ogi di San Giovanni ... in guesta [sic] prima parte l'acresiamento della republicha a che modo la e' reusita sotto diversi bononi de piu imperatori et ladunation fatossi insieme et a che modo che lorro governava la citta per salute di populli. Il fine della prima parte."|5. fol. 23v-54r, Book 2: "In questo secondo tratato dell regionamento della citta de Trevigi seguita le tiranide del crudelissimo Eccialino fina alla morte sua ... gente a piedi et a caval persone sei milia capetanio general erra m[onsignore?] Jacomo dal Verme veronese."|6. fol. 56r-78r, Book 3: "Habiando habuto il ducal dominio di Venegia la citta de Trevigi et pacificato il populo montenendo bona ragione m[onsignore?] Gulielmo Guerini ... A di setembrio 1549 fo ritrovato atachato in molti lochi de Trevigi alli muri el ditto de segno qual dice porta corona viva lo mag[nifi]co generoso Joanne Renier."|7. fol. 81v-93r, Book 4: "In questo quarto tratato si contien le graveze che hano li habitanti de Trevigi come colta datii et la entrada ... li gualli se mandano al offerto di magnifici signori sop[r?] a le fortezze di terra."|8. fol. 97r-111v, Book 5: "In questo guinto tratato se contien le castelle del territorio et ville ... che comincio a divider la terra onde e venuto le citta le gente come si vede e pero contentiamosi nel grado che la fortuna ne guida. Vale."
