physical_description: Extent: 72 leaves : parchment ; 213 x 129 (153 x 70) mm bound to 220 x 132 mm
note: From the library of Ortenssio Barzella (1324), the manuscript passed into the collection of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 9323) "from Thorpe the bookseller in 1836," and later into the library of James K. Moffitt. Phillipps number 9323 pasted on spine. Front pastedown: bookplates of James K. Moffitt and Pauline Fore Moffitt Library, University of California, Berkeley. Front endsheet, verso, in modern pencil: "4675". Fol. i, recto, in modern pencil, "Reo" ["Rw"?]. Fol. 2r, partially erased ownership note: "Iste liber est [meus?] [----------?]"; also, in modern pencil: "619". Fol. 71v, erased ownership signature. Fol. 72r, in contemporary hand: "Questo sie de mi Ortenssio Barz"; and below: "Questo sie de mi Ortenssio Barzella 1324."|Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment; fol. i (paper) + 70 + i (paper); 1-58 64 7-88 910; quires signed on center back of folio of last leaf of gathering; numbered on the center bottom of the first leaf of each gathering in a later hand.|Layout: 28-30 lines of text, line-ruled in lead. Texts 1 and 3 ruled for one column of text and a narrower column of gloss. Double lines running length of page on left and right. Another vertical line on outer edge for gloss.|Script: Protogothic (a rounded gothic hand with elements of caroline minuscule).|Decoration: 6-line illuminated initial in red and gold with pen flourishes; 4-7-line initials, some inhabited, in red with pen flourishes. 2-line initials in red. Initial on fol. 68r appears to be of a different style.|Binding: Full leather binding over boards; 3 raised bands. Pastedowns and endsheets of marbled paper. On spine: "Horatius de arte poetica cum scholiis. M.S.N. Memb. SAEC. XI."|Origin: Produced in Italy in the 13th or early 14th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 64.|Former shelfmark: HOR 1.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PA6393.A7 1300.|1. fol. 2r-10r, Ars poetica: "Humano capiti cervicem pictor equinam Iungere si velit [wormhole]rias inducere plumas ... Quem vero arripuit tenet occiditque legendo Non missura cutem nisi plena cruoris hyrudo. [rubr.] Explicit liber poetrie Oratis."|2. fol. 10r-45v, Sermones: "[rubr.] Et incipit sermonum [text] Quid fit Mecenas ut nemo q[ua?]si forte seu ratio dederit seu fors obiecerit illa ... Ut nichil omnino gustaremus velut illis Canidia afflasset peior serpentibus Afris."|3. fol. 46r-71v, Epistulae: "[rubr.] Incipit liber epystolarum Oratii [text] Prima dicte m[ih]i suma dicende Camena Spectatum satis et donatum iam rude queris ... Tempus abire tibi est nepotum largius equo Rideat et pulset lasciva decentius etas. [erasure (of ownership note?)] Explicit liber Oratii Deo gratias s[a]l[ute]m 3 s Qui i scrisit i scribat semper a[nim]i domino vivat vivat. [another erasure (of ownership note?)]."

note: From the collections of the Rev. Richard Farmer, Richard Heber, Sir Thomas Phillipps, F. Fenwick, L.W. Hodson (bookplate), Sir Sidney Cockerell, and John Gribbel.|Manuscript codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, fol. ii (modern paper) + 206 + ii (modern paper); 18 ( -3) 2-36 48 ( -4) 5-78 88 ( -2) 9-268 278 ( -1); catchwords at the end of each quire; quires signed a-z, &, [abbr. for "con"?], AA-BB; quires also numbered, last leaf verso, i-xxvi|Layout: Written in 2 columns of 42 lines, each column containing 6 stanzas of 7-line rime-royal verse; outer bounding lines ruled in hard point.|Script: Written in a semi-cursive script mainly by one hand; fol. 96, written in a second hand and pasted to a stub, evidently as a contemporary correction of an excised original.|Decoration: 2- to 3-line initials in blue with red pen-flourishing; paraphs at beginning of each stanza in alternating red and blue; marginal notations with alternating red and blue paraphs.|Binding: 17th or 18th cent. Top cover has been reattached several times, including recently.|Origin: Written in England, approximately 1480.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 75.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ4274 D285 1480.

note: From the library of the abbey of Melk, the manuscript passed first into the collection of Joseph Martini and then into that of James K. Moffitt. Fol. 1r and 20r, circular ownership stamp of the Benedictine abbey of Melk ("Bibliothek des Stiftes Melk"). Fol. ir: "4150" in black ink. Flyleaf: bookplate of James K. Moffitt.|Ms. codex.|Title on fol. 2r and 20r (in red); also on fol. 1r and fol. 20r in black in a later hand.|Collation: Parchment, iv + 20 + iv; 1-28 36; now foliated 1-20; medieval foliation from 57 [=1] to 76 [=20] still visible.|Layout: 22 long lines ruled in lead point. Initials and title in red, initials of verses washed in red.|Script: Gothic.|Decoration: 2-line initials in red with flourishes.|Binding: Modern morocco by Sangorski & Sutcliffe, London; originally formed fol. 57-76 of another book.|Origin: Produced in Germany in the 13th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 80.|Former shelfmark: MAR 25.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS QE362 M17.|1. fol. 1r [= ch. LXI, 1-21 in Migne, Patrologia Latina, 171, col. 1737-1770]: "Atjulus [sic] ut gemmam digitis aptandus haberet ... Propter quod lapidum titulo liber iste notatur."|2. fol. 1v-2r: "[capitula] Incipiunt capitula numero sexaginta. De adamante .i. De actate .ii. ... De criselectro .lix. De crisopatio .lx. Incipit liber Marbodi de lapidibus."|3. fol. 2v-20r: "[prologus] Evax rex arabum fertur scripsisse Neroni Qui post Augustum regnavit in urbe secundus ... Hec ex in numeris excepta vocabula gemmis Sufficiat nostro collecta labore teneri Que decies senis distincta patent capitellis. Explicit liber Marbodi de labidibus [another titled added later] Explicit liber Marbodi de lapidibus."

physical_description: Extent: 25 leaves : parchment, color illustrations ; 146-148 x 100-104 (88 x 60) mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 642:2) & positive (BANC MS UCB 82 FILM)
note: Arms of the House of Cleves in the first initial (fol. 1r); gift of Phoebe Apperson Hearst to the Bancroft Library. On front endsheet, recto: "271 2" pasted in. Front endsheet, verso, in ink, in upper left-hand corner: "7-3466". Back flyleaf, verso, in modern pencil, upper left-hand corner: "45 decorierte Seiten."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, 25; 1-28 38( -2) 44( -2).|Layout: 19 lines per page; traces of frame ruling in ink with vertical lines running entire length of page.|Script: Gothic in Franco-Flemish hand.|Decoration: 81 miniatures illustrating scenes from Genesis, life of Mary and life of Christ; some have been retouched. Two historiated initials: fol. 5r, Mary praying; fol. 24r, Christ on the cross. Floral border on 2r. Arms of the Duke of Cleve in 9-line initial on fol. 1r. Primary initials 7-9 lines in gold against red and blue ground or in blue with red flourishes. Small 1-line initials alternate in red and blue. Refrain "Ave Maria," names of days, and a few corrections (cf. 25v) in red.|Binding: Cut velvet over pasteboards; doublures in paper with wheel motif on brown ground. Binding now removed and stored with manuscript.|Accompanying materials: Former binding in box with manuscript.|Origin: Produced in the Duchy of Cleve (now Germany), as indicated by the coat of arms on fol. 1r and by the dialect (East Middle Dutch), probably the second quarter of the 15th cent. The illustrations are confined to the margins and may be of a later (1460-1480?) date.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 82.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BT306.28 1450.|Fol. 1r-25v: "Die daer in den beginne ghescapen heeft hemel ende eerde ende dat meer ende alle dat daer in is om te verclaren die ontspeekelike goetheit synre goedernerenheit. Amen. [red] Ave Maria ... Als hi begrauen was o du gemynde moder ende iofferouwe du gyngeste alre bedroeste moder en wech mit groten suchten ende wenen bislu weder geleit inden armen des gemynden Johannes."

title_as_recorded: La vie des Pères ; L'estoire del Saint Graal ; Merlin
subject_as_recorded: Catherine, of Alexandria, Saint--Legends|Lancelot (Legendary character)--Romances|Catherine, of Alexandria, Saint|Lancelot (Legendary character)|Arthurian romances|Grail--Legends|Manuscripts, French--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Arthurian romances|Grail|Manuscripts, French|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
material_as_recorded: parchment|parchment|negative (volume 1: BOX 642:3; volume 2: Box 866:5) & positive (BANC MS UCB 106 FILM)
physical_description: Extent: 191 leaves : parchment ; 337 x 223 (265 x 170-175) mm bound to 347 x 232 mm|Extent: 155 leaves : parchment ; 337 x 223 (260 x 172) mm bound to 347 x 232 mm|Extent: 2 microfilm reels : negative (volume 1: BOX 642:3; volume 2: Box 866:5) & positive (BANC MS UCB 106 FILM)
note: Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubrics (v. 1, fol. 1r, 92v, 101r, 105r, 105v, 111r, 117v).|Collation: Vol. 1: Parchment, fol. ii (modern paper) + 191 + ii (modern paper); 1-108 118 ( -1) 12-138 14-152 166 174 ( -1) 18-268 274 ( -1) (what would have been last leaf of last quire of vol. 1 is first leaf of first quire of vol. 2); catchwords throughout except after quires 10 and 16; quires signed incorrectly in modern pencil at end and beginning of each quire (tenth quire recorded twice, throwing signatures off by one); quires 23 and 24, signatures I-IIII visible in red ink. Vol. 2: Parchment, fol. ii (modern paper) + 155 + i (modern paper); first leaf of first quire of vol. 2 is what would have been last leaf of last quire of vol. 1; thereafter 1-108 118 ( -1) 128 13-148 ( -1) 15-168 174 ( -1) 186 19-208 214; catchwords throughout except after quires 11, 16-18 (catchwords at end of quire 12 do not match first words of next quire, stub visible indicating possible missing leaf); quires signed incorrectly in modern pencil after quire 10; contemporary quire signatures I-IIII consistently visible in red ink.|Layout: Vol. 1: fol. 1r-116v written in 3 columns of 48 lines, fol. 117r-191v written in 2 columns of 48 lines; vol. 2 written in 2 columns of 44 lines. The whole frame-ruled in red.|Script: Written in a French Gothic script by one hand, or possibly two hands. Corrections to text and added notes and passages by another hand in a lighter-brown ink.|Decoration: Elongated decorated letters in black ink extending into top and bottom margins. Rubrics in alternating red/blue, blue/red and, less numerous, red/pale greyish blue, flourished filigree paragraph initials. Elongations blue/red usually alongside cols. beginning a new story or poem. A large historiated initial (40 x 63 mm) at the beginning of v. 1, a three-tier composition, represents the Crucifixion, two monks, and a monk and the Virgin. A two-tier miniature (80 x 118 mm), fol. 145v, represents Cain killing Abel, and three large flowers. A second miniature (59 x 61 mm) at the end of v. 1 (fol. 191v) shows Christ rescuing Adam and Eve from the mouth of Hell (Harrowing of Hell) with a title on the right hand margin: "Mult fu iriez li enemis," pointing to the beginning of Merlin in the second vol. The historiated initial (48 x 50 mm) at the beginning of the prose text of the Saint Graal (v. 1, fol. 117) probably depicts the author, a monk, writing under the inspiration of an angel. Various incidents of the Grail story are depicted in 21 small or medium-sized historiated initials between fol. 119 and 190 (on: 119v, 121v, 125, 126, 134, 136, 137, 141v, 143, 145v, 160v, 167v, 168, 169, 170v, 183, 184, 187, 188(2), 190v) in many of which the Grail is represented as a spherical gold object.|Decoration (cont.): Vol. 2 has only one large historiated initial (55 x 68 mm) on the first leaf which represents four angry devils (very rubbed). The large historiated initials at the beginning of the two volumes are not as well-preserved as the smaller ones. The colors used are rather dull, mostly brown, reddish brown and blue, with some gold in the outer frames.|Binding: Early 19th cent. Elaborately ruled gilt calf binding with decorative bands by Le Febre; now 2 volumes but originally bound as one. Vol. 2: back cover detached.|Origin: French, possibly from the region of Paris-Amiens, Arras.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 106.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ1475 G68.|1. [v. 1] fol. 1r-92vb: La vie des Pères "[rubr.] Ici commence la vie des Peres. De ii hermits dont li un chai en fornicacion [text] Aide Dex rois Jhesu Crist / Pere filz et seins esperit / Dex qui tout pues et tout crias / Qui en la croiz seinte crias / Je muir de soif ce fu a dire / Que despit avoies et ire ... Si bien vos doint Dex de li estre / Que vos soiez mis a sa destre / En paradis en sa grant joie / Et je pri Dieu que il men oie Amen."|2. [v. 1] Fol. 92vb-101ra: Vie de Théophile "[rubr.] De Theofle qui fist homage au diable por richesce et terrien honeur avoir [prologue] A la loenge et a la gloire / En remembrance et en memoire / De la roine et de la dame / Qui je comanc mon cors et m'ame ... [text] Pour ceus esbatre et deporter ... Et sera totes nos acordes."|3. [v. 1] fol. 101ra-105vc: Le Conte dou Baril "[rubr.] Du Baril qui fu rampli dune lerme [text] En bon essample raconter / Puet ou tele chose escoter / Qui puis li a molt grant mestier ... Si qua samor puissons venir. Amen. Amen. Amen."|4. [v. 1] fol. 105rb-105vc: Les neuf joies de Notre Dame "[text] Reine de pitie Marie / En qui deite pure et clere / A mortalite se Marie / Qui es virge fille et mere ... Nos doint en cele haute yglise / o les ix ordres mansion. Amen."|5. [v. 1] Fol. 105vc-111rb: La passion Jesu Christ "[rubr.] La passion Ihesu Crist [text] Oiez moi trestouz doucement / que ni ait mot ne parlement ... Ab hoste nos eripiat."|6. [v. 1] 1 fol. 111rb-116va: La vie de Sainte Katerine "[rubr.] Ci comence la vie St Katerine [text] Nos trovomes en nos ecris ... Disom amen, que Dex lotroit [added explicit] Ci faut la vie seinte Katerine."|7. [v. 1] fol. 117ra-191vb: Le Saint Graal "[text] Cil qui la hautesce et la seignourie de si haute estoire com est cele du graal ... Mais or se test li contes de totes le lignies qui de Celidoine issirent et sen torne a une branche que len apele lestoire de Merlin quil covient a fine force a aioster a lestoire du seinte Graal, por ce que brance en est et i apartient. Si comence Merlin Robers de Borron en tel maniere [text next to miniature] Mult fu iriez le enemis."

physical_description: Extent: 6 leaves : parchment ; 247-257 x 149-180 (192-215 x 112-140) mm. bound to 258 x 190 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (966:1) & positive (BANC MS UCB 88)
note: Ms. fragment.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fragment of 4 leaves in one gathering + 2 individual leaves.|Layout: Fol. 1r-5v: written in 2 columns of 9 lines; frame-ruled in dry point with double outer vertical bounding lines, three middle vertical bounding lines and 1 inner vertical bounding line; fol. 6r: written in 11 long lines, possibly ruled in ink (parchment too blackened to tell).|Script: Written in Caroline miniscule; fol. 1r-5v by one hand, fol. 6r-v by a second hand.|Decoration: Fol. 1r-5v: initials in red with yellow infilling.|Music: Fol. 1r-5v: neumes on staves consisting of a red F line and a yellow C line; fol. 6r: northern French notation with a red F line (yellow C line may have been present at one time, but leaf is very darkened).|Binding: Modern paper wrapper (back cover bears watermark of 8-pointed star with circle with in the center).|Origin: According to John A. Emerson, the Tonary (fol. 1r-5v) comes from southern France and the antiphoner (fol. 6r-v) from northern France. Paul Merkley writes that the fragment was likely written in Italy.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 88.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS uncat 1966 11.33.

note: Folio tipped in before first flyleaf contains a note in ink transcribing opening rubric and providing a general description of book; in a different hand in pencil is the name Giovanni [last name illegible]. Fol. iiv contains the name Marco Barcella.|Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubric (fol. 1r). Title at head of the 1st leaf the same as in the printed edition of Berthold Ruppel and Michael Wenssler, Basel, not after 1479.|Collation: Paper, fol. ii (modern paper and parchment) + 254 + i; 1-2012 2114; catchwords written vertically at the end of each quire.|Layout: 2 columns of 40 lines; horizontal rules in ink, vertical rules in lead.|Script: Fol. 1-5v written in an upright humanistic book hand; thereafter text written in a humanistic cursive script, perhaps by several hands; copious marginal notes in several hands.|Decoration: 1 gold initial with white vine-stem decoration on ground of blue, purple and green; 2-line initials in red, blue and black with remaining letters of initial words often in square capitals; sermon titles and paragraph marks in red; some spaces throughout for unexecuted 1- and 2-line initials.|Binding: Old vellum; 2 decorative leather reinforcements on spine; fore-edge leather ties (1 broken).|Origin: Likely from Northern Italy or Basel, Switzerland.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 89.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS uncat 1966 11.34.|Fol. 1r-252v: "[rubr.] Sancte theologie magistri necnon sacri eloquii preconis celeberrimi fratris Roberti de Liteo ordinis minorum professoris opus quadragesimale perutilissimum quod de penitentia dictum est, feliciter incipit. [title] [Dominica] in septuagesima de facilitate bonorum operum seu bene operandi propter quam peccatores ad penitentiam redire debent. Sermo primus. [text] Multi sunt vocati pauci vero electi ... Sollicite igitur providendum est ut ab [ipsis] impiis separati per bona opera et veram [penitentiam] innumerari valeamus angelicis choris ordinibusque sanctorum collaudantes et benedicentes deum per immortalia seculorum secula. Amen. [rubr.] FINIS."

physical_description: Extent: 131 leaves : parchment ; 265 x 184 (201 x 157) mm bound to 273 x 183 mm|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 1034:5) & positive (BANC MS UCB 105 FILM)
note: Manuscript belonged to the classical scholar Michael Wodhull and bears his arms; later came into the possession of the Rev. Henry Drury, of Harrow; then entered the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps. On front cover, the arms of Michael Wodhull. Pasted on spine, Phillipps no. 3380. On front pastedown, pasted in and partially defaced, coat of arms with motto, "[L?---] GREX." On flyleaf, in pen, in the hand of Michael Wodhull, "call'd in the Cat: a Ms. of the 13th century" and below, "collat. & complet." Also on flyleaf, stamp of Rev. Henry Drury of Harrow, dated 1818. On fol. 131v, in ink, top left corner, "Cl. Pe. De franccastel ." On 131v, in ink in lower right hand corner, "2 £ 1/2." Traces of etching or drawing on fol. 131v.|Ms. codex.|Title from incipit (fol. 2r).|Collation: Parchment, fol. ii + 131 + ii; 1-2 8 36(+1) 4-158 1610; quires signed 1-16 in a later (17th cent.?) hand.|Layout: Fol. 1v in 2 columns, remainder 16 lines of Biblical text ruled in hard point and occasionally lead; 40-56 lines of gloss in margins and top and bottom of page. Prickings visible.|Script: Early rounded gothic hand except for first 7 lines of fol. 2r, which are in uncials; 1 scribe for both text and gloss. Marginal notes in a 17th century hand.|Decoration: Inhabited initial on fol. 2r, decorated with white interlace pattern and blue, red and green, which extends the length of the text. 1- and 2-line secondary initials in text are red; other initials touched with red up to fol. 37r. First initial of gloss on each page is 2 lines and decorated with pen flourishes.|Binding: 18th cent. French mottled calf; spine gilt in compartments, gilt inner borders, gilt edges, marbled endpapers. Title on spine: "Genesis Latine M.S. Antiq. In Membran."|Origin: Produced in the 12th century in France, probably in Paris.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, fMS UCB 105.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS1234.L2.|1. fol. 1r: Extensive notes in 17th century hand on different editions of Vulgate, including publication dates.|2. fol. 1v: "[col. 1, gloss] Notandum quia Moyses in hoc libro de inferiori mundo in quo hoc factus est semonem facere intendit ... Dehinc sequentur distinctiones diversorum operum. [Augustine, PL 113, col. 64B] [col. 2: rubr.] Gregorius. [text] Quaerendum nobis est quoniam deus simul cuncta condidit ... In est vero ei etiam cum non apparet fructus et semen quia nimirum simul sunt in radicis substantia quae non simul sunt prodeunt per temporis incrementa" [Paterius notarius Gregorii I, PL 79, col. 688B].|3. fol. 2r-130v: "Incipit liber Bresith idem Genesis. In principio creavit deus caelum et terram . et expletis cx vitae suae et conditus aromatibus repositus enim in loculo Aegypto."|4. fol. 131r: "Joseph igitur qui sicut pater eius Jacob terram repromissionis tota menta disiderabat ... Adimplebis me domine leticia cum vultu tuo delectationes in dextera tua usque in finem."

physical_description: Extent: 41 leaves : parchment ; 228 x 164 (144 x 93) mm. bound to 236 x 161 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 642:5) & positive (BANC MS UCB 109 FILM)
note: Apparently presented by Christine de Pisan to Jean, duc de Berry, who soon gave it away. Sir. Thomas Phillipps acquired the manuscript from Payne. On front pastedown, in ink, illegible ownership signature. On front free endpaper, in ink, "les epitres de debat sus le Roman de la rose," and below, in pencil, " From Payne 1824." Fol. 1r, Middle Hill stamp, and below, in ink, "236." Fol. 40r, in ink, erased and only partly legible, "Ce livre est au duc de Berry, Jehan." Below, an inscription in another hand, also partly erased, "Ce livre est a ... et li donat mons. Le duc de Berry a Melun a Paris." Below that, in the same hand, "Fine, [--]me " Below, in a modern hand, in pencil, "this Ms belonged to John, Duc de Berry, see his signature above." Fol. 41v, in red ink, in a different gothic hand, "Memento dantis. Accipito datum placide dantisque memento Sic quod non vento des quod tibi corde precatur." Below, in another hand, also in gothic script, "Amen dico." On back pastedown, in bâtarde script, "Christine de Pisan [----]."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 41 + i; 18 26 (+1) 3-48 5[beta]0; quires signed a-e; catchwords at end of quire.|Layout: 25 lines rule in lead; frame-ruled.|Script: Bâtarde; headings in red; in the hand of Gontier Col, secretary of Jean, duc de Berry.|Binding: Tawed leather over wooden boards, early 15th century, with 4 raised bands and sewn end bands. Remains of 2 side clasps on front; manuscript title label on back cover ("Christine de Pizan [-]recloquente"). "236" pasted on spine.|Origin: Written in France in the court of Jean, duc de Berry, ca. 1402-1410.|Byname: Le débat sur le Roman de la rose.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 109.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ1529.P48.E6.

physical_description: Extent: 112 leaves : paper and parchment ; 213 x 138-145 (145 x 85-87) mm. bound to 224 x 147 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 784:10) & positive (BANC MS UCB 111 FILM)
note: Manuscript may have been owned by a member of philosophical circle of Mordecai Comtino, Elijah Bashyazi and Caleb Afendopolo in late 15th cent. Constantinople. Later owned by a Karaite in the area of the Crimea (cf. book lists on fol. 17v and 39v). Discovered by Ephraim Deinard at Theodosia in the Crimea ca. 1876; sold by him to the Ladies Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El, San Francisco, who donated it to the Library of the University of the University of California, Berkeley, Feb. 1897. On front pastedown: "Semitic Library of the University of California, Gift of the Ladies of Temple Emanu-El, San Francisco, Received February, 1897. Accession no. 64883."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper and parchment, fol. i + 112 + i; [collation is approximate; the manuscript has been damaged by sea water, and many folia and bifolia have been pasted in] 116 (+1?) 212 310 410 (+3 pasted in) 54 (+1) 6-712 812 (+3 pasted in) 96 108 (+2 pasted in).|Layout: 26 lines per page. No visible ruling. Catchwords at lower left bottom of every folium.|Script: In one hand, with notes in two other hands (cf. fol. 17v, 39v, and 112v).|Binding: Modern binding over pasteboards; cloth on spine, which is deteriorating.|Accompanying material: Two separate pages, written by Ephraim Deinard, describing his discovery of the manuscript in a 10th cent. synagogue in the Crimea in 1876, and the water damage to the manuscript during a storm on the Sea of Azov in Oct, 1876.|Origin: Produced in southern France or Spain in the 14th or 15th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 111.|Former shelfmark: MAR 1.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS B485.L3A7.|3. fol. 18r-39v: Supercommentary on Averroes' Middle commentary on Aristotle's Meteorologica, beginning defective.|4. fol. 39v: Poem and list of books in the possession of the former 18th cent. owner (same hand as fol. 17v).|5. fol. 40r-41v: From Levi ben Gershom's supercommentary on Averroes' Middle commentary on Aristotle's De interpretatione.|6. fol. 42r-49v (lacuna between fol. 48v and 49r): Levi ben Gershom's Supercommentary on Averroes' Middle commentary on the Isagoge of Porphyry, beginning defective.|7. fol. 50r-57v (lacuna between 55v and 56r): Supercommentary of Levi on De interpretatione.|8. fol. 58r-65v: Isagoge to the end.|9. fol. fol. 65v-97r: Levi ben Gershom, Supercommentary on Averroes' Middle commentary on Aristotle's Categoriae.|10. fol. 97r-112r. Levi ben Gershom, Supercommentary on Averroes' Middle commentary on Aristotle's De interpretatione.|11. fol. 112v: Notes.

physical_description: Extent: 209 leaves : paper ; 207 x 150 (140 x 97) mm. bound to 205 x 159 mm.
note: From the library of Phoebe Apperson Hearst.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper (heavy, waxed), fol. ii (parchment) + 209 + ii (parchment); 10[beta]2 ( -1) 2-17[beta]2 186; each quire is numbered at beginning and end.|Layout: 2 columns of 22 lines; columns of text enclosed in decorative, long, closely-spaced double red lines, with arches at top which serve as vertical bounding lines; horizontal lines ruled in dry point; present also are shorter vertical lines rules in lead in margins which serve as guidelines for decorative, symmetrical patterns; first few opening lines of each pericope in red; section numbers in margins against text and concordances in lower margins.|Script: Written in bolorgir script by one hand.|Decoration: 4 full-page illuminated miniatures of the four Evangelists: Matthew (fol. 3v), Mark (fol. 61v), Luke (fol. 101v), and John (fol. 161v); opening page of each gospel has ornate, intricate decoration with floral motifs; other illustrations are marginal ornaments and decorative initials; all decoration is characterized by bright colors including orange, magenta, blue, purple, and pink, with generous application of gold.|Binding: Worn velvet binding over boards, flush with book-block; stiff fore-edge flap attached to bottom cover; trace of large cross in middle of top cover, and other ornament on both covers; traces of 8 bosses, one in each corner of top and bottom covers; red edges with decoration on upper and lower edges toward the spine; 4 raised bands; sewn end-bands laced in.|Origin: Surviving fragment of colophon states that the scribe was a cleric named Nicholas. According to Sanjian (see 510 note) he is probably the same scribe who wrote the Four Gospels at Kafa in the Crimea (1656) now in the Case Memorial Library at Hartford (Armen. 4).|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 113.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS2554.A7.

physical_description: Extent: 260 leaves : parchment, color illustrations ; 282-284 x 182 (189 x 123) mm, bound to 292 x 188 mm
note: Front pastedown, pasted in and written in pen, "L.J. III. 6." Front free endpaper, in ink, "Lyonel Tollemache. This manuscript was in the Old Library at Helmingham. N.B. Collated. The new Testament perfect, The Lessons imperfect." Pen markings on fol. 125 r and fol. 131r. Erasure (ownership signature?) on bottom of fol. 254r. More erasures on top of fol. 261r, as well as doodles and erasure on fol. 261v. Once belonged to Tollemache Library of the Earls of Dysart in Helmingham, Suffolk (Helmingham MS 45); passed into Bibliotheca Bodmeriana near Geneva.|Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 261 + i; 16 (missing first fol.) 2-178 186 19-338 344 ( -1); quires of the calendar are unsigned; quires of the Bible are signed a-z (with the sequence o-p-q repeated); catchwords in decorative frames at end of quire.|Layout: 2 columns of 32-34 lines per page; frame-ruled in ink with double lines at top, bottom, and margins for running title and marginal finding aids. Some prickings visible.|Script: Gothic script, with addition of Anglo-Saxon letter thorn.|Decoration: 14 7- to- 8-line illuminated initials on square gold ground with full borders with gold decoration; 13 6- to 8-line parti-colored blue and red initials with full borders of red and blue pen-flourishing; 3-line initials in alternating blue and gold with red or lavender. Many initials rubbed.|Binding: English tan calf, 16th century; narrow band borders of black and white enamel pigment within gold rules; inner panel with central medallion, all in gilt with enamel pigment scrollwork; two side clasps catching in back. Title on spine: "M.S. New Testam. & Lessons out of the Old Testament. Helmingham." Binding attributed to the "Morocco binder;" see Nixon, H.M. "Elizabethan gold-tooled bindings." (In Essays in honour of Victor Scholderer, p. 219-270), p. 239|Origin: Produced in England in the last decade of the 14th century for a noble patron.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 128.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BS135.4.W93.

physical_description: Extent: 61 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 407 x 251 (294 x 168) mm. bound to 410 x 261 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) + 61 + i (paper); 1-210 3-58 610 78 ( -1); catchwords at end of each quire, some framed and decorated; 1st quire signed.|Layout: 2 columns of 65-90 lines; ruled in lead and dry point.|Script: Written mostly in littera bononiensis in 3 hands: Scribe 1, fol. 1r-20r, 37r-61v; scribe 2, fol. 21r-36v; 3rd hand, humanistic cursive, fol. 44r-45r.|Decoration: 4 large painted initials with leafy extensions into margins; 3-line initials in alternating red and blue with pen-flourishing of the other color; paragraph marks within text in alternating red and blue. Bartolus de Saxoferrato's treatise on water-rights illustrated with geometrical diagrams apparently depicting land-plots and their relationship to water-courses; generally the rivers are shown flowing from the mouth of a dog.|Binding: 19th cent. half-leather over pasteboard; 5 raised bands; contiguous endsheet and pastedown.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 103.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS 2MS uncat 1967 5.16.|1. fol. 1r-20v: "[rubr.] Incipit lectura domini Dyni, super titulo de regulis iuris VI libri decretalium, scripta anno Domini millesimo ccxlxi [or ccxl. xi (die)] de mense Aprilis [text] Premissis casibus singularibus et eorum determinatione in precedentibus titulis singulariter intellecta ... actionem cedendam alterius non ut ... [truncated: end of extant text]."|2. fol. 21r-44r: [Unidentified text on procedural law] "[Index] i. Quid sit accusatio et quando accusator sit necessarius ... xxxvi. De multis questionibus dependentibus a statutis [text] Accusare autem nil aliud est quam deferre alium reum criminis in libello ... illud confici."|3. fol. 44r-45r: "[Title] Epistola Magistri Petri Yspani ad Imperatorem Ferdericum [sic] de sanitate corporis conservanda. [text] Clarissime Pater, cum a sompno aliquantulum ambullare debetis ..."|4. fol. 45r-61v: [Bartolus de Saxoferrato, Tiberiadis] "[text] Tyberiadis est regio iuxta flumen Tyberis ..."

physical_description: Extent: 156 leaves : parchment ; 346 x 236 (272 x 170) mm. bound to 365 x 240 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 966:6) & positive (BANC MS UCB 108 FILM)
note: Monastery of San Paulo Fuori le Mura, Rome, 12th cent. ; Giambattista Petrucci; bought of Payne and Foss by Phillipps (his no. 12273).|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment (thick and yellowish), fol. i (paper) + 156 + i (paper); 1-198 204; catchwords (some cropped, some missing).|Layout: 2 columns of 36 lines; ruled in hard point, single bounding lines; pricks visible.|Script: Written in a transitional script by one hand.|Decoration: 20 large initials in red, decorated in void and followed by a line of calligraphic capitals touched with red; 2- to 4-line initials in red; initials within text touched in red.|Binding: 19th cent. half-roan by Bretherton.|Origin: Written in Italy in the 12th cent. by one Johannes: "Scripte sunt a Iohanne clientulo clientulorum Almi Pauli. Adolescens enim haec scripsit" (fol. 94r).|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 108.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX 2435 C28.|1. fol. 1r-10v, Book I. fol. 1r: "[rubr.] Incipit Collatio prima Abbatis Moysi de monachi destinatione vel fine. Incipiunt capitula [text] i. De habitatione Scythi et propositione Abbatis Moysi ... xxiii. De sermone doctoris secundum audentium meritum ... [rubr.] Explicunt capitula." fol. 1r-1v "[rubr.] Incipit prologus in libro decem Collationum Patrum [text] Debitum quod beatissimo Pape Castori in eorum voluminum prefatione promissum est ... Sed nunc iam ad Collationes eorum et institute properemus. [rubr.] Explicit prologus." fol. 1v-10v: "[rubr.] Incipit liber primus id est Collatio prima Abbatis Moysi de destinatione [text] Cum in heremo Scythy ubi monachorum probatissimi Patres et omnis commorabatur perfectio ... tam digestae Collationis inflammati gaudio quam repromissae disputationis."|2. fol. 10v-20r, Book II. fol. 10v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula de secunda Collatio [sic] eiusdem senis [text] Degustato. i. Proemium Abbatis Moysi super discretionis gratiam ... xxvi. Responsio de non excedendo refectionis modo." fol. 11r-20r: "[rubr.] Degustato itaque matutino sopore ... ac sine contemplatione certi finis attingi omnino non possit. [rubr.] Explicit capitula."|3. fol. 19v-28v, Book III. fol. 19v-20r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula de Abbatis Pafnutii Collatione [text] i. De conversatione ac vita Abbatis Pafnutii ... xxi. Responsio quod liberum arbitrium nostrum adiutorio Domini semper indigeat." fol. 20r-28v: "[rubr.] Explicit Collatio secunda Abbatis Moysi discretionis gratia. Incipit liber tertius id est Collatio prima Abbatis Pafnutii de tribus abrenuntiationibus capitula libri huius require in Collatione prima Abbatis Moysi [text] In illo sanctorum choro qui velud [sic] astra purissima in nocte mundi istius refulgebant ... ne auditu quidem nos antea percepisse nossemus. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Pafnutii de tribus abrenuntiationibus."|4. fol. 28v-36r, Book IV. fol. 28v-29r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula libri quarti id est Collationis Abbatis danielis de concupiscentia carnis ac spiritus. [text] i. De vita Abbatis danielis ... xxi. De his qui contemptis magnis occupantur in parvis." fol. 29r-36r: "[rubr.] Incipit liber quartus id est Collatio prima Abbatis danihelis de concupiscentia carnis ac spiritus. [text] Inter ceteros Christiane philosophie viros Abbatem quoque vidimus danielem ... non abiecit divitis voluntatem. [text] Explicit Collatio Abbatis danielis de concupiscentia carnis ac spiritus."|5. fol. 36r-45v, Book V. fol. 36r-36v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula Collationis Abbatis Serapionis [text] i. Adventus noster ad Abbatis Serapionis cellam et inquisitio de generibus et impugnatione vitiorum ... xxvii. Quod non idem proeliorum ordo sit qui ponitur in catalogo viciorum." fol. 36v-45v: "[text] Incipit liber quintus, hoc est Collatio prima Abbatis Serapionis de octo vitiis principalibus. [text] In illo cetu antiquissimorum senum fuit vir nomine Serapion ... ut eas quodammodo ante oculos positas intueri nobis velut in speculo videremur. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Serapionis de octo vitiis principalibus."|6. fol. 45v-53v, Book IV. fol. 45v-46r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula de Collationis Abbatis Theodori. [text] i. Descriptio heremi et inquisiti de nece sanctorum ... xvii. Quod nemo ruina subitanea conlabatur." fol. 46r-53v: "[rubr.] Incipit libri sexti id est Collatio Abbatis Theo de nece sanctorum. [text] In Palestine partibus iuxta Thecue vicum, qui Amos prophetam meruit procreare ... sub illius questionis interrogatione cognovimus. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Theodori de nece sanctorum."|7. fol. 53v-65r, Book VII. fol. 53v-54r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula de Collationis prime Abbatis Sereni capitula [sic]. [text] i. De castitate Abbatis Sereni et interogatione praedicti senis super statu cognationum nostrarum ... xxxiii. Dilatio super absolutionem proposite quaestionis." fol. 54r-65r: "[rubr.] Incipit liber septimus, id est Collatio prima Abbatis Sereni de anime mobilitate et spiritalibus nequitiis. [text] Summe sanctitatis et contentie virum ... duplicato gaudio conferemus. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Sereni de mobilitate animae et spiritalibus nequitiis."|8. fol. 65r-75r, Book VIII. fol. 65r-65v: "[rubr.] Incipit capitula [sic] eiusdem Collationis secunde. "[rubr.] i. De humanitate Abbatis Sereni ... xxv. De diabolo quod est et pater eius." fol. 65v-75r: "[text] Incipit liber octavus, id est Collatio secunda Abbatis Sereni de initio principatus nequitiarum. [rubr.] Consumatis quae diei sollemnitas exigebat ... quam ante venientes doctrine eius plenitudinem sitiremus. [text] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Sereni de initio principatus."|9. fol. 75r-86v, Book VIIII. fol. 75r-75v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula de [sic] Collationis prime Abbatis Ysaac premium. [rubr.] i. Verba Abbatis Isaac de orationis qualitate ... xxxv. De utilitate brevis ac tacite orationis." fol. 75v-86v: "[text] Incipit liber nonus hoc est Collatio prima Abbatis Ysaac de qualitate orationis. [rubr.] De perpetua orationis atque incessabili iugitate quod in secundo institutionum libro promissum est ... nec dum nos integre percepisse illis disputationibus senseramus. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Ysaac prima de oratione."|10. fol. 86v-94r, Book X. fol. 86v: "[rubr.] Incipiunt capitula liber [sic] decimi eiusdem senis. proemium [rubr.] i. De consuetudine quae super significationem Paschae intra Aegipti provinciam retenatur . xiii. Responsio quemadmodum stabilitas cordis seu cogitationum possit adquiri." fol. 86v-94r: "[text] Incipit liber decimus hoc est Collatio sedunda Abbatis Ysaac de oratione. [rubr.] Inter haec anachoretarum instituta sublimia ... ad Deum versiculi huius meditatione servaverint ... [text] Explicit liber decimus id est Collatio decimus. E Collationes [sic] videlicet decem quae misse sunt ad Papam Leontium et Elladium. Scripte sunt a Iohanne clientulo clientulorum Almi Pauli. Adolescens enim haec scripsit, primicie namque scriptionum eius sunt iste Collationes. Unde obnixe deprecatur ut quicumque haec legerit non vituperet eum sed potius bene [dicat] ut addatur ei sapientia similes et contimore Domini et vita aeterna."|11. fol. 94r-103r, Book XVIII: "[rubr.] Incipit Collatio Abbatis Piamon de tribus monachorum generibus. [rubr.] Emissis iuvante gratia Christi decem Collationibus sub Patruum ... ipso primum imbuente suscepimus. [text] Explicit liber Collationis Sancti Abbatis Piamon de tribus generibus monachorum."|12. fol. 103r-109r, Book XVIIII. fol. 103r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt Abbatis Iohannis de fine cenobie et heremite. [rubr.] i. De cenobio Abbatis Pauli et patentia cuiusdam fratris ... xvi. Responsio quibus documentis possit agnosci. [text] Explicit capitula." fol. 103r-109r: "[text] Incipit liber. [rubr.] Post dies admodum paucos maioris doctrinae desiderio pertrahente ... Hoc Abbas Iohannis cum hore none refectionem imminere sensisset, Collationem fine conclusit. [text] Explicit Abbatis Iohannis de fine cenobie et heremite.|13. fol. 109r-114v, Book XX. fol. 109r-109v: "[rubr.] Incipit Collatio Abbatis Pinufi de penitentie fine et satis factionis indicio [text] i. De Abbatis Pinufi humilitate et eiusdem latebra ... xii. In quo temporaliter sit agenda penitudo et in quo finem habere non possit." fol. 109v-114v: "[text] Incipit Collatio Abbatis Pinufi [rubr.] Preclari ac singulari viri Abbatis Pinufi ... cum retinere non posset, emisit. [text] Explicit liber Abbatis Pinufi de penitentie fine et satis factionis indicio."|14. fol. 114v-128r, Book XXI. fol. 114v-115r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt Abbatis Theone de remissione quinquagesime capitula. [rubr.] i. Quomodo Theonas ad Abbam Iohannem venit ... xxxiiii. Responsio quod haec questio future Collationi debeat reservari. [text] Explicit capitula." fol. 115r-128r: "[text] Incipit liber Abbatis Theone de remissione quinquagesime. [rubr.] Priusquam verba Collationis huiusce habite cum summo viro Abbate Theona incipiamus ... Scilicet non studioso loquacitatis infructuose, sed desiderio purificationis interne. [text] Explicit Abbatis Theone de remissione quinquagesime."|15. fol. 128r-135v, Book XXII. fol. 128r-128v: "[rubr.] Incipit eiusdem de nocturnis illusionibus. [rubr.] i. De iterato ad Abbatem Theonam reditu nostro eiusque exortatione ... xv. Dilatio proposite questonis expliciunt caput." fol. 128v-135v: "[text] Incipit liber. [rubr.] Post dies ferme septem quinquagesime solemnitate transacta ... disputationis vela pandamus. [text] Explicit Abbatis Theone Collatio secunda de nocturnis illusionibus."|16. fol. 135v-146r, Book XXIII. fol. 135v-136r: "[rubr.] Incipiunt eiusdem de anamarteton Collatio tertia [rubr.] i. Disputatio Abbatis Theone de eo quod Apostolus dicit: non enim quod volo facio bonum ... xxi. Quod licet agnoscamus nos sine peccato non esse, non debeamus tamen nosmetipsos a dominica comunione suspendere. [text] Explicit capitula." fol. 136r-146r: "[rubr.] Incipit liber." [text] Reversa igitur luce cum per ad scrutandam [sic] ... aut otiosa oblivione depereunt. [rubr.] Explicit Abbatis Theone Collatio tertia de anamarteton."|17. fol. 146r-156v, Book XXIIII. fol. 146r-146v: "[rubr.] Incipit Abbatis Abrahe Collatio de mortificatione. Incipit [sic] capitula. [rubr.] i. Quomodo Abbati Abrahe cogitationum nostrarum arcana prodiderimus ... xxv. Quemadmodum perfecte renunciatibus centuplum in hoc mundo repromittatur. [rubr.] Explicit capitula." fol. 146v-156v: "[rubr.] Incipit liber. [text] Quarta atque vicesima ista Collatio Abbatis Abraham christo favente procluditur ... nunc ad tutissimum silentii portum spiritalis orationum vestrarum aura commitetur. Amen. [rubr.] Explicit Collatio Abbatis Abrahe de mortifcatione. Deo gratias. Amen."

note: A device, probably that of the original owner, is written on the original blank leaf following the end of the text: "Sobriete Nourisse de Vertu/De fortune Dieu ma comble." Robert Lang; his sale, Evans, bought by Payne. Passed into the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 3636).|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1r).|Collation: Paper ("Ancre" and, in the last two gatherings, a letter "Y," similar to Briquet 9186), fol. ii + ii + 169 + ii; 1 12 218 314 48 516 68 718 814 9-1116 1218( -5); catchwords at end of each quire, quires signed, some cropped.|Layout: 41 long lines per page; ruled in lead.|Script: Written in a secretary script by one hand.|Decoration: 2-line initials in red or blue; first letters of every line touched with red as far as f. 3, thereafter with yellow.|Binding: Straight-grained red morocco with gilt decoration, 19th century.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, fMS UCB 110.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ1533 T57.|Fol. 1r-171v: "[text] Alidone ot a nom la Royne au corps gent Anulomgue en fit ... note: Stamped spine label reads: "Mora Ms. n. 176."|Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubric (fol. 1r).|Collation: Paper, fol. i + 40 + i (contemporary foliation upper right margin); 110 28 (+1)? 38 410 58 68 (+1)? 74; catchwords on fol. 18v, 28v, 136v.|Layout: 21 long lines; double bounding lines ruled in hard point.|Script: Written in a hybrida script by one hand.|Decoration: Red monogram of Christ centered in upper margin of 1st page of text; headings in red; red initials and paragraph marks often with red pen-flourishing; 1-line initials slashed with red.|Binding: Parchment with floral paper covering; paper cut at corners, edges, and vertically towards spine, and parchment colored brown to resemble half-leather binding; stamped pattern on spine, painted gold, to resemble bands; also on spine, small gold flowers and an owl at tail; sewn end-bands laced in.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 116.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ4299 C25.|1. fol. 1r-26r: "[rubr.] Morali extrati del opera di Ceco Dascoli poeta ulgare eprima dela fortuna eventura [text] Non val ventura chi non sa fadica. Perfecto bene non fa senza pena ... Laso legancie e torno su nel vero. La fabule mi sono sempre nimiche [rubr.] Qui finisseno alcuni morali utoli e iocundi a sapere de Cesco [sic] Dascoli."|3. fol. 34v-36v: "[Iacopone da Todi: text] Dona del paradiso / el tuo fiolo e preso / Iesu Christo beato ... Se glie tolto el vestimento / lasame aver vedimento / Como el duro batimento" [text ends here, but catchword indicates continuation: "tuto la insanguinato"].|4. fol. 37r: "[beginning of text wanting] ... Conto ma beato numero sacrato cum santa Maria / miser San Stefano primo cavaliero / Laurenzo beato mori volentiera et ... Santa Katarina dongella cortese / de Iesu sposa cum beata Doratea / compagna cara cum Santa Margarita [rubr.] Amen."|5. fol. 37v-38v: "[text] Isti sunt versicoli psalterii sanctissimi quos nominavit diabolus invictus beato Bernardo. Et fertur magne devocionis meriti, et sunt isti [text] Illumina oculos meos ne umquam obdormiam in morte ne quando dicat inimicus meus prevalui adversus eum ... Et omnibus fidelibus vivis et defunctis in tera viventium vitam et requiem sempiternam concede [text] Amen."|6. fol. 36v-40v: [text] Pregam Yesu nostro Salvatore / che perdonanza doni al pecatore ... O fiolo fiolo tal consa non dire / fiolo mio con tego io volglio morire ..." [text is incomplete].

physical_description: Extent: 135 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 153 x 120 (90 x 58-64) mm. bound to 160 x 122 mm.
note: Formerly owned by Florence S. Walter. Gift of her daughter, Mrs. Paul Bissinger, to The Bancroft Library.|The name "Charles" appears on fol. 3v, 4r, 43r; the name "Cahots" on fol. 107v; notes in French on fol. 3v (with date of 1593) fol. 4v (with date of 1589), and on fol. 49r.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation (largely conjectural, based on physical evidence and on amount of missing text): Parchment, fol. vi (modern parchment) + 135 + vi (modern parchment); (one quire of 6 leaves missing initially) 1⁶ 2⁸ ( -1 before fol. 7) 3⁸ 4⁶ ( -an added leaf before fol. 6) 5⁸ ( -an added leaf before fol. 33) 6⁸ 7⁶( -2 center bifolia between fol. 44-45) 8⁸ ( -5 before fol. 50) 9⁶ ( -an added leaf before fol. 56) 10(? only fol. 59 remains) 11⁸ ( -1, 2 before fol. 60; -8 before fol. 65) 12⁸ ( -3 before fol. 67; -7, 8 before fol. 70) 13⁸ ( -1 before fol. 70) 14⁸ 15⁸ ( -8 before fol. 92) 16-20⁸ 21⁴ (? now all mounted singly on tabs); catchwords, usually in script of text, in center lower margin.|Layout: 13 long lines ruled in pale red ink.|Script: Written in a formal gothic book hand in 2 sizes according to liturgical function. Fol. 133v-135 by a different scribe.|Decoration: 4- and 3-line initials in white-patterned blue or pink on burnished gold ground with border the length of the text in sprays of gold leaves, acanthus, flowers, and strawberries. 2-line initials in gold on alternating white- patterned pink or blue grounds with border extensions 1/2 length of text; 1-line initials in similar style but lacking extensions. Ribbon line fillers in white-patterned pink and blue with some gold, or in shape of flowers. Rubrics in red.|Binding: Stiffly bound (ca. 1930-1940 in San Francisco by Florence S. Walter) in tan calf inlaid with red, blue, and green morocco; stamped in gold to form central panel of tree resting on half-moon ground; binder's stamp on inner back cover. Pink silk doublures; gilt edges over red.|Origin: Written in France towards the middle of the fifteenth century for use in Poitiers, as shown by the liturgical use of the Hours of the Virgin, and by the use of the Office of the Dead; in the calendar and in the litany are saints of local veneration in Poitiers.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, MS UCB 117.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, 2MS BX2080 1450.|1. fol. 1r-6v: calendar in red and black, beginning defectively in July and including feasts of Generosus (16 July), Junianus (12 August), Radegundis (13 August, in red), Philibert (20 August), Gelasius and Justinus (26 August), Flavia (5 October), Benedict (23 October), Martin of Vertou (24 October), Florentia (1 December), [Venantius] Fortunatus "episcopos pictavensis" (14 December).|3. fol. 15r-21v: Pericopes of the Gospels, that of John followed by the prayer, Protector in te sperantium ... [Perdrizet, 25].|5. fol. 60v-63r: Passion according to John, followed by the prayer, Deus qui manus tuas ...|8. fol. 92r-133r: Office of the Dead, use of Poitiers, beginning defectively.

physical_description: Extent: 134 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 176 x 125 (103 x 65) mm. bound to 182 x 132 mm.|Extent: 7 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 176 x 125 (107-112 x 70-75) mm. bound to 182 x 132 mm.
note: Inscription and date on fol. 1r, "D. Bercé De courpont 1714, M."|Inscription on fol. 133v, 16th/17th cent.: "se present livre apartyent a usemenne femme de de s qui Les trouvera sy Luy rende et Il paira Le vin."|In pencil on fol. ii: "D838/27" and below that, "£225/-/-."|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. iv (modern parchment) + 134 + 7 (from a different book) + iv (modern parchment); 1-26 36 ( - 1 and 6) 4-128 1310 14-168 176 (through fol. 128) 186 (fol. 129-124) and 7 single leaves from a different book; catchwords usually present horizontally in lower right corner in bâtarde script.|Layout: Fol. 1-134: 16-17 long lines per page, ruled in pale red ink, with top two and bottom 1 horizontal lines full across. Fol. 135: 17 lines of text; fol. 136-141, 14 lines of text, all ruled in brown ink with top and bottom 2 lines full across.|Script: Fol. 1-134 written in 2 sizes of a spikey formal gothic book hand; fol. 135-141 written in 2 sizes of a somewhat rounder gothic book hand.|Decoration: Fol. 1-134: Twelve miniatures above 4 lines of text in arched compartments with borders of painted gold grounds decorated with red and blue, pink and blue, and white over blue acanthus, grapes, strawberries, flowers and tendrils. 4-line initials, shaded white, over rose on painted gold ground with floral infilling; secondary initials, 2-line, in same style as 4-line; 1-line initials in painted gold on brown or brick red square grounds; line fillers as gold-patterned brick red rectangles or as logs; rubrics in bright orange-tinged red ink. Spaces left blank above 4 lines of text for miniatures on fol. 129, 131; in this quire none of the initials executed (except in modern pencil).|Decoration: Fol. 135-141: 7 miniatures (suffrage of Stephen, Coronation of the Virgin; Annunciation with angel; Nativity with Infant; Virgin enthroned; suffrage of James the Greater; David and Bathsheba) have been added ca. 1480 to a book produced ca. 1450, since style and iconography do not seem coherent with the style of the borders or the initials. Miniatures above 3 lines of text; the first, fifth and sixth miniatures show the patron or patroness. Full borders of painted gold and blue acanthus, flowers, birds, insects against a natural ground. Major initials (4- or 3-line) in burnished gold on white-patterned blue or pink ground with infilling. Fol. 136v has parted red and blue 5-line initial with elaborate fine flourishing of both colors; 2- and 1-line initials alternating red and blue; 1-line initials within the text washed in yellow; red or blue paragraph marks; rubrics in red; line fillers as continuous red zeros or as red and blue jigsaw patterns.|Binding: 19th cent. rebacked purple velvet over wooden boards; chased gilt fore-edge clasp; gauffered and gilt edges.|Origin: Written ca. 1480 for use in the diocese of Evreux, as shown by the liturgical use of the Hours of the Virgin and the Office of the Dead, and by the saints present in the calendar and the litany.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 131.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2080.E87.|1. fol. 1r-12v: Calendar, rather empty, in French in red and black including the feasts of William of Bourges (10 January), Gaudus (31 January), Ansbert (9 February), Benedict of Nursia (21 March), Eutropius (30 April), Nicolas of Bari (9 May, in red), Desiderius (23 May), Gildard (8 June), Leufred (21 June), Translation of Martin (4 July, in red), Benedict of Nursia (11 July), Aquilinus (18 July), Victor (21 July), Germanus of Auxerre (31 July), Transfiguration (6 August, in red), Taurinus (11 August, in red), Philibert (20 August), Invention of the relics of Taurinus (5 September), The Three Marys (22 October), Romanus (23 October), Martin (11 November, in red), Nicolas of Bari (6 December, in red).

note: From the library of Professor Charles W. Jones. Front endsheet: "£160-150" in pencil, upper left corner. Below, in modern pencil: "S. Agostino, manoscritte Sec. XIV̊." Below, in modern pencil in another hand, "Florence, 27 November, 1920". On fol. i, recto, bookplate of University of California ("Gift of Professor Charles Jones"). On fol. 42v, at top, in pen: "160". At bottom in same hand: "160". Below that, in another hand: "M nter[-?]i 18."|Ms. codex.|Title from explicit (fol. 42v).|Collation: Parchment, iii (paper) + 42 + iii (paper); 1-48 56 66( -2); catchwords at end of each quire.|Layout: 18 lines per page; most pages frame-ruled in ink with double horizontal lines extending across page at top and bottom of written space; vertical outer lines also extend full length of page. Folia at end and beginning of each quire (cf. fol. 8v-9r) have additional (unused) ruling at upper and lower borders and at sides. Prickings visible.|Script: Gothic script, with marginal notes in a later hand in semi-gothic cursive (cf. fol. 33r).|Decoration: Full floral border on all sides of text on fol. 1r with red and blue flowers, birds, and fruit. Primary initials (2-3 lines) in orange and red with green in-filling on gold ground with floral and gold flourishes; red initials with gold infilling and flourishes. 2-line initials in red or purple with gold, blue, and green in-filling and pen flourishes. Incipits and headings in red.|Binding: Limp vellum. Quires attached to spine with 2 thongs laced in.|Origin: Produced in Italy in the 15th cent.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley MS UCB 132.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley 2MS BR65.A8.

physical_description: Extent: 167 leaves : parchment ; 142 x 102 (103 x 75) mm. bound to 150 x 108 mm.
note: Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 492); sold at Sotheby's (16 June 1910, lot 117); gift of Professor Charles W. Jones to the Bancroft Library.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) + 175 + i (paper); 1-310 4-58 610 (+1?) 710 8-148 15-1810 198; quire signatures I-III, V on fol. 10v, 20v, 30v and 46v; some catchwords (fol. 10v, 20v, 30v, 46v, 67v, 75v, 91v, 137v, 147v, 157v, 167v).|Layout: 2 columns of 31 lines, prickings visible.|Script: Written in a gothic script possibly by 2 hands (change of hand on fol. 47r and 73r).|Decoration: Initials, occasionally terminating in fish or monstrous heads; line fillers as fish and grotesques; opening initial in blue with red and blue pen-flourishing; 2- to 4-line initials decorated in void and either red or blue decoration; 1-line initials within text touched with red; marginal notes occasionally enclosed in red frames.|Binding: 19th cent. half-leather and marbled paper over pasteboard by Phillipps; 3 raised bands sewn in; contiguous endsheet and pastedown.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 134.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX1749 B64.|1. fol. 1ra-72va, Saint Bonaventure, Breviloquium: "[rubr.] Incipit breviloquium Fratris Bonaventure [text] Flecto genua mea ... donec intrem in gaudium Domini mei Dei qui est trinus et unus Deus benedictus in saecula saeculorum. Amen. [rubr.] Explicit iste liber qui Breviloquium sive Veritas theologie nuncupatur."|2. fol. 73ra-73va, Anonymous: "[text] Iupiter misit pomum aureum de celo in terram ... ad patriam celestis gratie ad que bona nos perducat qui vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen."|3. fol. 73va-122ra, Petrus de Remis, Sermones de communi sanctorum: "[rubr.] Incipit opusculum generale de Sanctis. De apostolis [text] Qui sunt hii qui ut nubes volant ... ad regna perducat ..."|4. fol. 122ra-175vb, Lucas de Bitonto: "[rubr.] Incipiunt sermones speciales pro festis notabilibus et specialibus annis . De adventu sermo et epistola [text] Hora est iam nos de sompno surgere ... Explicit iste liber qui Veritas totius theol[o]gie vel Flos florum nuncupatur. Explicit expliceat ludere scriptor eat."

physical_description: Extent: 128 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 128 x 88 (78 x 45) mm. bound to 137 x 91 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubrics (fol. 1r, 53r, 103r).|Collation: Parchment, fol. i + 128 + i; 1-310 48 510 68 7-1010 116 1210 13-148; catchwords placed at the end of each quire, lower right hand corner, perpendicular to text block.|Layout: Frame-ruled in dry point with lines extending to borders of page; 17 lines per page. Prickings visible on some pages.|Script: Text in humanistic book script; titles and names of characters in rustic capitals.|Decoration: Title page of each work is illuminated. Fol. 1r has 5-line initial inhabited by Cicero, crowned with laurel. Border decoration of flowers, animals, putti, and foliage in green, blue and red on gold background. 5 black and white medaillions in the style of ancient cameos at the corners and top. 2 small color portraits at sides and coat of arms at bottom. The other title pages, fol. 53r and 103r, are similar: title in gold letters on purple ground; first words in gold on red; 4 or 5 cameo busts at corners and at top or bottom; borders of rabbits, flowers and foliage in green, blue and red on gold ground. Elsewhere: 2-3 line gold initials on red or blue background with leaves. Full border on fol. 54v, with flowers and foliate decoration in gold, blue, green and yellow. Finally, an elaborate later doodle on fol. 102r.|Binding: Contemporary (?) binding, blind-stamped with rope pattern; 3 raised bands sewn in, end bands sewn in; surface cracking of spine leather, front hinge split at top (1"), 2 fore-edge clasps missing; all edges gilt and gauffered.|Origin: Produced in Italy (possibly Ferrara) between 1470 and 1490.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 142.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PA6304.L2M24.

physical_description: Extent: 138 leaves : parchment, col. ill. ; 320 x 240 (230 x 170) mm. bound to 330 x 240 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 968:8) & positive (BANC MS UCB 144 FILM)
note: Owned originally, or soon after writing, by Antoine Aubin, who wrote "Se present livre est amoy que me nome Anthoine Aubin A.A." in ink in contemporary hand on the middle of fol. 1r.; later by Pierre Havre de Metz, who wrote "Ce beau livre appartient a Pierre Havre de Metz presantement a Ribanilla Luz 1679" in ink in contemporary hand at the top of fol. 1r.; later by Jehan Pierre Crosset; then it belonged to a German noble family. Donated to The Bancroft Library by Alfred E. Heller, Clarence E. Heller, and Elizabeth H. Mandell in honor of the 80th birthday of their mother, Elinor Raas Heller.|Ms. codex.|Title from opening rubric (fol. 2r).|Collation: Parchment, 135 + i; 16 24 3-58 66 7-178 188( -2); catchwords at end of some quires.|Layout: 2 columns of 39 lines; ruled in ink.|Script: Bâtarde.|Decoration: 2 large initials on painted cusped grounds with floral infilling and bar borders for beginning of poem; 2-line initials in alternating red and blue; first letter of each line washed in red or yellow; speech-prefixes in red; partial borders in gold, silver (tarnished).|Origin: Produced in France in the third quarter of the 15th cent.|Binding: Original wooden boards, partially bevelled at upper, lower and fore edges; the calf back partly covering the sides, with repeated longitudinal rows of gilt stamps of a rose divided by gilt fillets; the remainder of each side covered with pale cream velvet, having a delicate branded design of a curled leaf and a blossom, and 11 ornate bronze studs on each side, single chased bronze catch and clasp, edges gilt.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 144.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS PQ1527.A1.

note: Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. iii (paper); [tentative analysis] 11 (presumably of 10 leaves, of which only last remains) 210 ( -3, after fol. 3) 310 ( -4-8, after fol. 13) 410 510 ( -10, after fol. 34) 610 ( -3, after fol. 36; -5-6, after fol. 37 -9, after fol. 39) 710 ( -4, after fol. 43; -6, after fol. 44; -1 after fol. 47) 810 ( -2, after fol. 48; -4, after fol. 49; -6, after fol. 50; -9, after fol. 52) 910 ( -1, after fol. 53; -3-4, after fol. 54; -7, after fol. 56) 1012 ( -5, after fol. 63; -11-12, excized by scribe with no loss of text after fol. 68) 1110 ( -3-4, after fol. 70) 1210 ( -7, after fol. 82); one quire signature "xxvi" (fol. 68v); one catchword (fol. 77v). Parchment, single sheet|Layout: 3 columns of text: central column contains the psalter written on 16 lines with 2 lines of space for interlinear gloss between each; commentary on the psalms, written in columns ruled for 48 lines of text, surrounds the central column; ruled in lead; prickings consistently visible on the tail of each fol. and intermittently visible on the head and fore-edge, suggesting trimmed edges.|Script: Written in an early gothic script in one hand.|Decoration: Large initials the height of 3 lines of biblical text in alternating red and blue with infilling in other color; 1-line initials within text in red; occasional initials within the commentary section in blue and gold.|Binding: 20th century white leather with gold tooling.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 147.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS B1425 L3 1200.

note: Fol. 1r, in ink: "Je suis [erasure] [p?]louj[a?]z," then in another hand, "M. Le [V?]u[-]n" and above, in same hand, "sin." Fol. 246v, ownership note written upside down and too faint to read. Fol. 247v, another ownership note, also written upside down and nearly illegible.|Ms. codex.|Title devised by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, fol. iv (paper) + 247 + iv (paper: watermarks of unidentified letters); 112 28 ( -1) 3-78 88 ( -4?) 98 ( -2) 108 118 ( -1) 128 ( -2) 138 ( -1) 148 ( -1) 15-168 178 188 ( -3?) 19-288 298( -1) 30-338; catchwords.|Layout: 12 lines per page; frame-ruled in red ink with lines extending length of page.|Script: Bâtarde; 3 scribes.|Binding: 18th century sheep; 4 raised thongs laced in; sewn endband on top.|Decoration: 3 miniatures (scourging of Christ, fol. 75r; Christ carrying cross, fol. 81v; and Mother and Child enthroned, fol. 229r); unfinished miniatures on fol. 46r (sketched in but never completed), 76v, and 91r. Offset from excised miniatures on fol. 12v, 61v-62r, 69v, 86, and 123v, and 212v. Panel borders throughout, with flowers, fruit, and acanthus leaves and birds and animals; later borders in gold and white on colored ground. Illuminated 2- and 1-line initials and line-fillers in burnished gold on red and blue ground with white trace later initials in colors and liquid gold.|Origin: Core of book begun in the area of Angers approximately 1460 but not finished; further text and illuminations added to the book approximately 1475 in Rouen in the same workshop that produced MFA 04.1745.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 167.

subject_as_recorded: Catholic Church--Hymns--Texts|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Spanish--California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 69 leaves : paper ; 139 x 104 (110 x 79) mm. bound to 145 x 110 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, fol. ii + 69 + ii; 14 2-612 74 (+1); no catchwords or signatures.|Layout: 24-28 long lines; some ruling in lead visible.|Script: Written in two distinct scripts: hymn stanzas in gothic script in dark brown ink with use of uncial letters, glosses in a smaller gothic bâtarde script in lighter brown ink; at least 7 different hands appear in marginalia and fragmentary texts used as guard pages; marginalia to primary text in Castilian and Latin in at least 2 contemporary early 16th cent. gothic cursive scripts with humanist tendencies; modern notations in pencil on fol. 39r.|Decoration: 12-line decorated initial on fol. 5r in red and brown ink; 4 3-line figural capitals with human faces in the center of the letter on fol. 4rv; 3 pen illustrations; guide letters for the rubricator appear in margins.|Binding: Full calf over pasteboard; 2 14th cent. vellum cuttings in gothic textualis script pasted to the spine and front board serving as title pieces, pasted cutting on front board reads "Ecce uideo celos apertos, et Ihesum stans," with 2-line initial "E" in blue, a blue decorative pax christi abbreviation, and a blue border, cutting on spine reads "unda deum, celum vidit ecce et fili[um]," modern paper fly leaves, edges stained red.|Origin: Probably produced in Northern Spain, possibly Navarre.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 177.|1. fol. 1r: Grammar fragment in Latin (unidentified).|2. fol. 1v-2r, Brief notice concerning a local indulgence: "[text] Esta es la summa mesura de nuestro señor ihesu xristo ... Questa medida santa [?] en la yglesia de san martin delante [el] altar de santa maria fue sacada esta medida de la longura del cuerpo de dios nuestro señ[or] ihesu xristo stavan presentes buenas personas [?] canonigos de la yglesia de san martin año de mil et cuatrocientos et cincuent[a] et nueve."|3. fol. 2r-4v: Anonymous Latin catechism with pericopic Latin and Castilian glosses (incomplete).|4. fol. 5r-68v: "[text] Primo dierum omnium quo mundus extat ... [gloss] constructo omnino nos todos surgamus leuantemus octius id est primo die en el primero dia omnium dierum en todos los dias."|5. fol. 69r: Continuation of Latin catechism with pericopic Latin and Castilian glosses (from fol. 4v).|6. fol. 69v: Contract fragment in Latin and Castilian (unidentified).

title_as_recorded: De l'amour de Leriano a Laureolle
subject_as_recorded: Manuscripts, French--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Renaissance--California--Berkeley|Manuscrits français--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscrits de la Renaissance--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscripts, French|Manuscripts, Renaissance|California--Berkeley
physical_description: Extent: 56 leaves : parchment ; 248 x 169 (172 x 104) mm. bound to 256 x 175 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (Box 3522) and positive.
note: Eighteenth-century shelfmark copied in upper left corner of fol. 1r: "O.356"; Robert Lang, Portland Place, London, his sale, London, Evans, 17 November 1821, lot 1311; Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 3631), sale London, Sotheby's, 30 November 1971, lot 524. Pasted on spine: "3631."|Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2r.|Collation: Parchment, fol. i (paper) + 56 + ii (paper); 18 2-96; no catchwords or signatures; foliated in modern pencil; errors in foliation: 44-56 numbered 45-57.|Layout: Up to 29 long lines (justification 105 x 170 mm.), frame ruled in light red ink.|Script: Written in a bâtarde with calligraphic features by one hand in brown ink.|Decoration: Space left for decorated initials with guide letters traced in ink.|Binding: 18th cent. polished light brown calf, back sewn on 5 raised thongs, title labels in red and green morocco, gilt spine, gilt frame on boards composed of a triple gold fillet, edges gilt (a few scratches to boards). Title on spine: Amours de Leriano.|Origin: Although it is not proven that the manuscript originated in the circle of the court of Francis I, it is accepted that all known manuscripts are datable between 1522 and 1526. The translator, François d'Assy, was employed by the early 1520s by Louise de Valentinois, daughter of Charlotte d'Albret and Cesare Borgia and, by 1526, he was the secretary to Louise and Henry d'Albret, King of Navarre. This translation was apparently composed for Jacquette de Lansac, widow of Alexandre de Saint-Gelais (died 1522). Because Jacquette is presented as a widow in the illuminated dedication copy (Paris, BnF, MS nouv. acq. fr. 7552), the translation must date after 1522, but probably before 1525, date of the privilege of the first known edition (Paris, Galliot du Pré, 1526).|Former shelfmark: O.356.|Former shelfmark: Phillipps MS 3631.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 178.|1. fol. 1r: "[title] Roman [crossed out and corrected to "Letre"]. Amours de Leriano et de Laureolle, Mss. du 15e siecle." fol. 1v ruled but blank.|2. fol. 2r-5r: "[title] Ce present livre a este translate de langaige tosquam florantin en francoys et traicte de lamour de Leriano a Laureolle, fille du roy de Macedoyne. [text] Depuis la guerre faicte en finye de l'an passe venante tenir mon yver et me repouser en mon pouvre repaire ... Pour me donne aucun soulagement en confort, meslant raisons discretes avec larmes piteuses, me comenca a dire en ceste manyere."|3. fol. 5r-53r: "[title] Le prisonnier. [text] [A]ucune part de mon cueur desiroit tenir livre presentement pour me louer de toy ... [title] L'acteur. [text] Quant a escripre les funerailles, pompe et sollempnites, debvoirs et honneurs mortuiures saichez qu'il luy furent faiz selon le merite et loyer de ses vertuz." fol. 53v-56v ruled but blank.

title_as_recorded: Memorial de los derechos patrimoniales pertenecientes en la Capital y Reyno de Valencia, y corte de Madrid al Exm̃o. Señor Dn. Carlos Joseph Gutierrez delos Rios Fernandez de Cordova, Suarez de Mendoza Zapata Argote Angulo Bocanegra Rohan Chavot, Conde de Fernan Nuñez, señor delas villas y Castillos de Abencaliz, y la Morena, Grande de España de primera clase, Gentil Hombre de Camara de S.M. con egercicio, Cavallero dela Ynsigne orden Toyson de Oro, y de la Gran Cruz de la Real y distinguido orden Española de Carlos 3o. Comendador delos Diezmos del Septeno en el orden de Alcantara. Consejero del Real y supremo Consejo de Estado, Mariscal de Canpo de los Reales Excercitos de su Mag[esta]d Enbajador de la corte de España cerca de su Mag[esta]d Fidelisima, residente alpresente como tal enla corte de Lisboa y nombrado ultimamente por S.M.C. para en enbajador cerca de su Madesta Britanica /

language_as_recorded: Spanish; some marginal notes in Latin
physical_description: Extent: 60 leaves : paper ; 172 x 96 (120 x 61) mm. bound to 179 x 100 mm.|Extent: 1 microfilm reel : negative (BOX 1836) & positive (BANC MS UCB 161 FILM)
note: Belonged to a Grante (19th cent.?); then in the library of Richard Heber, and later passed into the library of Sir Thomas Phillipps (his no. 8248). On spine: Phillipps no. 8248 pasted on; also "1047" pasted on. Front pastedown, in ink, the name "Grante"; below, bookplate of the Bancroft Library.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Paper, fol. i + 60 (Briquet, 13745, 8130, and 9753) + i; 1-106; vertical catchwords.|Layout: Ruling for three 8-line stanzas per page, frame ruled in red, with double lines on top for headings and on bottom and on left margin for marginalia.|Script: Humanistic, with headings in rustic roman capitals. 3 scribes: A, 1-88; B, 155-188; C, 188-300.|Binding: 16th cent. goatskin; 4 raised thongs; sides paneled with quintuple rules, border of repeated lozenge tools with quatrefoil, central panel filled with diaper of fleur-de-lys.|Decoration: Decorative ascenders and descenders on top and bottom lines, first initial of each line washed with yellow; headings in red; unexecuted initials.|Origin: The binding, watermarks, and textual variants suggest that the manuscript was produced in Southern France, perhaps Franche-Comté, which was then a possession of the Spanish crown. The date appears on fol. 49v: "anno incharnationis Iesus Christi M Quingentesimo qui[nto] decimo."|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 161.|2. fol. 2r-49v: "[heading] Propone [text] [A]l muy prepotente don Johan el Segundo / A quel con quien Juppiter tuvo tal zelo / Que tante de parte le hize en el mundo / Quanta as si mismo se hyze en el cielo / A gran rey d'España yal Cesar novello ... [heading] Fin [text] Ha box de sublime autoridad / Subito luego me fue presentada / Escrive tu dicho nodes fin a nada / Crescan tu obra diziendo verdar / Que vicio no haze la prol[un?]dad / Do trae buen modo de satisfazer / Si puede favor prestar te plazer / Favor est el mundo de mi magestad [Greek letters] Telōs tō theō charēs [Latin letters] Anno incharnationis Iesus Christi M Quingentesimo qui[nto] decimo [Greek letters, in a different hand] Telōs tō theō charēs [date of 1515 again, in Latin, in an almost illegible hand]."
