subject_as_recorded: Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)--California--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Medieval--California--Berkeley|Manuscrits latins médiévaux et modernes--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscrits médiévaux--Californie--Berkeley|Manuscripts, Latin (Medieval and modern)|Manuscripts, Medieval|California--Berkeley
language_as_recorded: Latin, with some instructions in French
physical_description: Extent: 108 leaves : parchment, color illustrations ; 126 x 83 (72 x 46) mm bound to 133 x 84 mm
note: Acquisition note in upper right corner of fol. 2: "nef[uncertain letter; possibly a price code], Dawson Turner, bought at Paris, 1814." The library of Dawson Turner (1775-1858), father-in-law of Sir Francis Palgrave, Deputy Keeper of the Public Records, was dispersed at auction by Sotheby's on 7 March 1853|Contents list of the volume on fol. 1v, signed by, or attributed to, the Rev. Frederick Charles Husenbeth (1796-1872), a Roman Catholic priest and prolific editor and author.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Collation: Parchment, ii (modern paper) + i (flyleaf) + 108 + i (parchment) + ii (modern paper) + ii (pastedown from Glossa Ordinaria); fol. 2 and 3 are contemporary leaves, ruled but blank; 16 ( -3 before fol. 1) 26 36 ( -1 before fol. 10 and 1 before fol. 13) 4/+8 \( -1 before fol. 15) 5-68 78 ( -1 before fol. 43) 810 ( -1 before fol. 47) 98 ( -1 before fol. 53) 108 ( -stub extended with handmade paper before 65, and -1 before 65) 11(? single folio) 128 (leaves glued before fol. 68) 13-148 158 ( -1 before fol. 95 and 1 after fol. 95) (3 incomplete quires removed and placed in box with former binding: 162 176 184) 198 ( -1 before fol. 96) 206.|Layout: 21 long lines (but 17-19 on fol. 63-64v and 66-67v, written by a second scribe; the two sets of leaves are apparently not conjoint); ruled in pale red ink with single bounding lines, both horizontal and vertical full length.|Script: Written in an elegant formal bâtarde script; fol. 63-64v and 66-67v copied by a second scribe in a larger and rounder version of the same script.|Decoration: Of the original 24 miniatures, only 11 remain, 8-10 lines in height and enclosed by narrow gold square frames, with full borders with multicolored acanthus, birds, flowers, insects and fruits on painted gold ground. Miniatures include Luke, Matthew, the Visitation, the Nativity, Annunciation to the shepherds, Adoration of the Magi, and Presentation in the temple, suffrages of Andrew and Stephen. Calendar miniatures, some in poor condition, formed of panels the length of the text block in the outer margin, divided into 3 compartments: monthly occupation, floral panel, sign of the zodiac. 2-line initials in leafy shaded white over blue or pink, on gold-filigreed red ground, with infillings of balls, snails, flies, butterflies, or animal heads against painted gold ground. 1-line initials in painted gold; borders run the length of the text and may include grotesques; line fillers in shape of gold logs.|Binding: Original binding consisted of brown morocco over pasteboards with a simple frame and cross, blind tooled on front cover, and gold tooled on the back, with a narrow gold rule around the top, outer, and bottom edge of the binding, and on the turn-ins; orange silk pastedowns; evidence of 2 fore-edge ties; gilt edges. In 1997 the book was rebound in full brown goatskin by the UC Conservation Department. Back paste-down from another manuscript now forms fol. v-vi.|Accompanying materials: Original binding now stored in box with codex.|Origin: Written in northern France, perhaps in the area of Bourges, during the 1480s. On fol. 1; notes in ink, all in the same careful hand (almost certainly that of Dawson Turner but difficult to compare against the signature), report the opinions of three people on the manuscript. The first note reads, "French; of the 15th Century: beautiful art. (Sir F. Palgrave)"; the second, "Sir F. Madden refers it to the years 1440 or 1450: he says that there is one by the same hand in the British Museum. (15 Jan. 1832)"; the third, "Mr. Shaw says that it may be French, or may be Flemish: beautiful, but of the most usual style of the 15th century. (Sept. 21 1835)."|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 139.|Former shelfmark: Berkeley, CA, The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, 2MS BX2080.B7 146x.|2. fol. 10r-11v: Pericopes of the Gospels, beginning defectively in gospel extract from John and ending defectively in gospel extract from Matthew.|6. fol. 63r-64v: Short Hours of the Holy Cross, beginning defectively.|7. fol. 65r-v: Short Hours of the Holy Spirit, beginning and ending defectively.|8. fol. 66r-93v: Office of the Dead, use of Rome, beginning defectively in Ps. 114:6.|9. fol. 93r-95v: Suffrages of the Trinity, Michael archangel, John the Baptist (rubric only), Andrew, Martin (rubric only, but perhaps in scribal error since the text continues on the top of the following verso), Stephen, Lawrence (rubric only).|16. fol. v-vi: Fragment from commentary from Glossa Ordinaria on 3 Kings VI. 16 and on Paralipomenon III. 6.

subject_as_recorded: Medina Sidonia, Alonso Pérez de Guzmán, duque de, 1550-1619|Medina Sidonia, Juan Alonso de Guzmán, Duque de, -1558|Guzman, Alfonso Perez de, 1256-1309|Guzman family|Guzman, Alfonso Perez de, 1256-1309|Guzman family|Medina Sidonia, Alonso Pérez de Guzmán, duque de, 1550-1619|Medina Sidonia, Juan Alonso de Guzmán, Duque de, -1558|Manuscripts, Spanish--Specimens|Manuscripts--Spain--Specimens|Manuscrits--Espagne--Spécimens|Genealogy|Manuscripts|Manuscripts, Spanish|Sanlúcar de Barrameda (Spain)--History|Niebla (Spain)--History|Cádiz (Spain : Province)--History|Spain--History--16th century|Spain--Genealogy--Early works to 1800|Cadix (Espagne : Province)--Histoire|Espagne--Histoire--16e siècle|Spain--Niebla|Spain|Spain--Cádiz (Province)|Spain--Sanlúcar de Barrameda|1500 - 1599
physical_description: Extent: 1 volume ([4], 464 leaves) : paper, illustrations ; 31 x 22 cm
note: Various hands, in black ink (title page ruled in red). Text on both sides of leaves. Numerous marginalia indicating years. Illustrations: 2nd prelim. fol.: Version of the coat of arms of Melilla: blue shield with two baskets checkered red-gold), out of which crawl ten snakes each. The border shows the arms of Castile and Leon (a golden castle on red and a lion on white). Above the shield a golden crown with a tower on which stands a knight dressed in golden armor with his sword drawn. Below the shield is a golden necklace linked together by blue flowers which is entwined with a green dragon.|Bound in full 19th century calf, spine gilt; gilt red morocco spine label: Illustrassiones de la cassa de Niebla.|The first part contains 6 books, which end at f. 331, covering the year 1540. The ending (f. 329-331) is a section of the verses (159-186) of the epic poem Laberinto de Fortuna by Juan de Mena. The second part (f. 333-438) contains 31 chapters. The third part covers f. 439-458. Fol. 458v-464v pertains to a separate author. Cortijo maintains that the remaining document was written by an anonymous author and reaches the year 1615.|Watermark: ovoid figure with circumscribed and crowned cross.|Later published as: Illustraciones de la casa de Niebla. [Madrid : Imprenta nacional, 1857] (cf. Palau 24552).|Part of: Fernán Núñez collection.|Shelfmark: Berkeley, CA The Bancroft Library, UC Berkeley, MS UCB 143 v.30.|Original shelfmark: C28-c7.

physical_description: Extent: 1 volume ([1], 340 leaves) : parchment and paper ; 34 x 27 cm
note: Written in sepia and red ink in two to three distinct hands in a Gothic script, in double columns, on both sides of leaves. First two folios are parchment, the rest is paper. Illuminated initials in red or purple ink, some with alternating purple or red ink decorative scrolls, which do not appear in all chapters although space has been left for them. Rubricated in red ink throughout. Pauses ('calderones') are in red ink. Numeration in red ink on top right hand margin until f. 123. Numerous marginal notes of various hands from the 15th-18th centuries. There is repeated misidentification of the author as Bernardo Aldrete (f. 34vb) in a 17th-18th century script.|Friction caused by rubbing has damaged ff. 1r and 2v, affecting legibility of the text. Numerous reparations to the leaves throughout. Fol. 3 is torn on the right margin and is suffering from deterioration. Likewise, many of the final folios (328-340) have been cut and/or torn and are deteriorating, leaving some with only fragments of legible text. F. 244 is loose from the binding.|Bound in 18th-cent. calf and marbled paper boards, spine gilt, green morocco spine label: Cronica general. Edges stained red.|Title from fly-leaf.|Dedication (f. 1r): Enel nonbre del padre e del fijo e del sp[irit]u santo.|Watermark: Two vertical bars connected with lines.|Part of: Fernán Núñez collection.
